title: Fowler v. Hunter
description: In this case, the defendant driver assigned the plaintiffs her professional negligence claim against the defendant insurance agent. The circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of the insurance agent finding the plaintiffs failed to prove damages.  We reverse, finding settlement agreements like the one in this case are beneficial and permissible, so long as there is no evidence of collusion.

THE
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In
  The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Eric U. Fowler and Melissa W. Dawn Fowler, Appellants/Respondents,
        v.
        Sallie Hunter,
          Gynecologic Oncology Associates,
        Selective Insurance
          Company of South Carolina, and Insurance Associates, Inc., Defendants,
        Of whom:  Selective
          Insurance Company of South Carolina is Respondent/Appellant,
        and
        Insurance Associates,
          Inc. is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal
From Greenville County
Â Larry
R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion
No. 4422
Heard
June 4, 2008 â€“ Filed July 8, 2008
Withdrawn,
Substituted and Refiled July 30, 3008
Withdrawn,
Substituted and Refiled October 28, 2008

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Rodney
          M. Brown, of Fountain Inn, for Appellant/Respondents.
        Andrew
          F. Lindemann, of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant.
        E.
          Matlock Elliott and Joshua L. Howard, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KONDUROS,
  J.:Â 
  Eric and Melissa Fowler (â€œthe Fowlersâ€) appeal the dismissal of their assigned
  cause of action for professional negligence against Insurance Associates, Inc.
  (â€œInsurance Associatesâ€). Â Selective Insurance Company of South Carolina, Inc.
  (â€œSelectiveâ€) appeals the dismissal of its cross-claim for equitable
indemnification against Insurance Associates.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
 The Fowlers were
  seriously injured when the motorcycle they were riding was struck by a car
  driven by Sallie Hunter.Â  The car was owned by Gynecologic Oncology Associates (â€œGOAâ€) for use by Mrs. Hunterâ€™s husband, Dr. James Hunter. Â Auto-Owners Insurance Company insured
  the car under a business automobile policy with limits of one million dollars.Â 
  At least two other policies potentially provided coverage.Â  One was a
  commercial umbrella policy for four million dollars procured by GOA through Insurance Associates and issued by Selective.Â  The other policy at issue was a
  personal catastrophic liability policy for two million dollars carried by the
Hunters and also issued by Selective. 
The Fowlers filed suit
  against Mrs. Hunter, and it was discovered that due to an inadvertent computer
  error by Insurance Associates, GOAâ€™s umbrella policy did not provide automobile
  liability coverage.Â  The Fowlers then filed a declaratory judgment action to
  see what coverage was available under the above-referenced policies. Â The
  Hunters and GOA answered and filed cross-claims against Selective for
  reformation and against Insurance Associates for professional negligence. Â Additionally,
Selective filed a cross-claim against Insurance Associates for indemnity.Â  
Eventually, the parties
  settled many of the claims in the two lawsuits. The Fowlers received one
  million dollars from GOAâ€™s automobile policy, two million dollars from the
  Hunterâ€™s personal umbrella policy, and an additional one and one-half million dollars
  from Selective.Â  Additionally, the Hunters and GOA assigned their professional
  negligence claim against Insurance Associates to the Fowlers, and the Fowlers
  signed a covenant not to execute against the Hunters and GOA.Â  The Hunters and GOA agreed to cooperate with the Fowlers in the prosecution of the professional negligence
  claim, and the Fowlers and Selective agreed to split equally any recovery from
either the professional negligence or indemnification claim.
Insurance Associates
  filed a summary judgment motion seeking dismissal of the only remaining claims:
  the professional negligence claim assigned to the Fowlers and Selectiveâ€™s claim
  for indemnification.Â  The circuit court granted these motions finding that
  because neither the Hunters, GOA, nor Selective could prove they were damaged
  by Insurance Associateâ€™s negligence, the claims failed.Â  These appeals
followed.
STANDARD OF
REVIEW
When reviewing
  the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard of
  review as the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis,
  366 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E.2d 437, 443 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Summary judgment is
  proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  To
  determine whether any triable issues of fact exist, the reviewing court must
  consider the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable
  to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrs., 368 S.C. 424, 434,
  629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).Â  However, when a party has moved for summary
  judgment the opposing party may not rest upon the mere allegations or
  denials of his pleading to defeat it.Â  Rule 56(e), SCRCP.Â  Rather, the
  non-moving party must set forth specific facts demonstrating to the court there
  is a genuine issue for trial.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Professional
Negligence
The Fowlers
  argue the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Insurance
  Associates as to their assigned claim for professional negligence.Â  We agree.Â  
The circuit
  court reasoned because the Hunters and GOA were insulated from execution of any
  judgment, the Fowlers, standing in the Hunterâ€™s shoes, could never prove
  damages flowing from the negligence of Insurance Associates.Â  While this
  analysis is technically correct, the majority of courts having addressed this
  issue have elected to allow such an assigned claim to proceed.Â  We are
  persuaded by the rationale set forth in those cases.Â  
In Campione v.
  Wilson, 661 N.E.2d 658, 660-61 (Mass. 1996), an injured party settled with
  an insurer and insured for a stipulated amount of damages and a release of the
  insured. Â The Massachusetts Supreme Court determined that even though the
  settlement included a release, the injured party could proceed in prosecuting
  the insuredâ€™s assigned negligence claim against the insurance brokers.Â  Id. at 663.Â  The court considered the competing policy considerations at play under
  these circumstances noting there is a risk of collusion between the settling
  parties even though there is benefit to allowing injured parties and
  tortfeasors to settle claims.Â  Id. at 662-63.Â  Nevertheless, the court rejected
  the â€œâ€˜somewhat metaphysical contentionâ€™ that the legal basis for the claim against
  the insurer [and broker] disappeared when the insured became insulated from
  liability due to a release or a covenant not to execute.â€Â  Id. at 662 (quoting Gray v. Grain Dealers Mut. Ins. Co., 871 F.2d 1128, 1132-33 (D.C. Cir.
1989)).Â Â  
An examination
  of other jurisdictions reveals most courts are approving of settlement
  arrangements similar to the one in this case, so long as the risk of collusion
  is minimized.Â  See Gray, 871 F.2d at 1133 (applying North
  Carolina law and allowing injured party to pursue assigned bad faith claim
  against insurer even though insured was insulated from liability by release); Damron
    v. Sledge, 460 P.2d 997, 999 (Ariz. 1969) (holding an assignment of the
  insuredâ€™s bad faith claim plus a covenant not to execute was not ipso facto collusive); United Servs. Auto. Assâ€™n v. Morris, 741 P.2d 246, 254 (Ariz.
  1987) (holding settlement between insured and claimant in which insurer was to
  defend under reservation of rights did not violate policyâ€™s cooperation clause); Red Giant Oil Co. v. Lawlor, 528 N.W.2d 524, 532-33 (Iowa 1995) (holding
  insured could still suffer damages from agentâ€™s negligence when settlement was
  coupled with a covenant not to execute that did not extinguish liability as
  would a release; therefore, assigned claim for agentâ€™s negligence would be
  valid); Glenn v. Fleming, 799 P.2d 79, 92-93 (Kan. 1990) (approving of a
  settlement between insured and injured party coupled with an assignment of a
  prejudgment claim and covenant not to execute when the settlement is entered
  into in good faith and the settlement amount is shown to be reasonable).
South Carolina has shown
  a willingness to depart from the common law in order to promote reasonable
  settlements between tortfeasors and injured parties.Â  In Bartholomew v.
    McCartha, 255 S.C. 489, 179 S.E.2d 912 (1971), our Supreme Court concluded
  the common-law rule regarding the Â release of one joint tortfeasor was not in
the best interests of justice.

  Being
    untrammeled by the ancient rule which, in our view, tends to stifle
    settlements, defeat the intention of parties and extol technicality, we adopt
    the view that the release of one tort-feasor does not release others who wrongfully
    contributed to plaintiffâ€™s injuries unless this was the intention of the
    parties, or unless plaintiff has, in fact, received full compensation amounting
    to a satisfaction.

Id. at 492, 179
S.E.2d at 914.
While acknowledging the
  inherent benefits of settlement, we also note South Carolina promotes the
  careful examination of settlement agreements to avoid the potential for complicity
or wrongdoing.Â  

  We are cognizant
    that litigants are free to devise a settlement agreement in any manner that
    does not contravene public policy or the law.Â  In fact, this Court encourages
    such compromise agreements because they avoid costly litigation and delay to an
    injured party.Â  However, these settlement agreements must be carefully
    scrutinized in order to determine their efficiency and impact upon the
    integrity of the judicial process.Â  

Ecclesiastes
  Prod. Ministries v. Outparcel Assocs., 374 S.C. 483, 493, 649 S.E.2d 494, 499
  (Ct. App. 2007) (quoting Poston by Poston v. Barnes, 294 S.C. 261,
263-64, 363 S.E.2d 888, 889-90 (1987)).
In the instant case,
  there is no evidence of collusion between the settling parties.Â  The injuries
  suffered in the case were extremely serious.Â  Furthermore, the parties did not
  put a stipulated amount of damages in their agreement so as to reduce the
  appearance of collusion, and because they contemplated that the underlying tort
  claim would be tried to a conclusion.[1]Â Â Â 
  The result of the settlement was the Fowlers were able to procure the three
  million dollars available under the other insurance policies in which coverage
  was not disputed, while litigation against a negligent party, Insurance
  Associates, was not foreclosed.[2]Â 
  This was clearly the intent of the parties as shown by the express language of
  the settlement agreement and covenant not to execute.Â  The catastrophic
  injuries suffered by the Fowlers begged a resolution that would give them the
  benefit of the uncontested proceeds promptly.Â  In light of our Stateâ€™s
  willingness to place the interests of the injured party above such a technical
  application of the law, we believe it was inappropriate for the claim to be
  dismissed at the summary judgment stage. Â We therefore reverse the circuit
courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Insurance Associates.Â Â  
II.Â  Equitable Indemnification
Selective contends
  the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Insurance
  Associates regarding Selectiveâ€™s cross-claim for equitable indemnification.Â  We
agree.
Under South Carolina law, a party seeking equitable indemnification must show three things: â€œ(1)
  the indemnitor was liable for causing the Plaintiffâ€™s damages; (2) the
  indemnitee was exonerated from any liability for those damages; and (3) the
  indemnitee suffered damages as a result of the Plaintiffâ€™s claims against it
  which were eventually proven to be the fault of the indemnitor.â€Â  Vermeer
    Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 63, 518 S.E.2d
  301, 307 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
Under
  the settlement, the
  Fowlers received one and one-half million dollars from Selective that was not
  directly traceable to any policy.Â  The circuit court determined Selective
  admitted liability under the commercial umbrella policy by making this
  payment.Â  If so, Selective actually benefitted from
  the negligence of Insurance Associates.Â  Had the automobile liability not been
  inadvertently excluded under the policy, the defendantsâ€™ potential exposure
  would have been the full amount of the policy limits amounting to four million
  dollars.Â  
Selective
  offered an alternative explanation for the one and one-half million dollar
  payment.Â  Selective contends the payment was made as part of a global
  settlement to avoid a professional negligence claim asserted by the Hunters and
  GOA.Â  Insurance Associates admitted its negligence in failing to request
  automobile coverage on the umbrella policy.Â  If Insurance Associates was acting
  as an agent for Selective, Selective could be vicariously liable for that
  negligence. Â Consequently, Selective argues it settled that claim for one and
  one-half million dollars, paid to the Fowlers, and decided to pursue
  indemnification from Insurance Associates.Â  We find Selectiveâ€™s position raises
  a question regarding the indemnification claim, but only if we can conclude
  Selective would not have issued the policy had the application been correctly
  submitted.Â  In other words, if Selective would have issued the policy anyway, it
  was not damaged by Insurance Associatesâ€™ negligence as it would have been
  exposed for the full four million dollars.Â  
As
  the moving party, Insurance Associates relied upon the deposition testimony of
  Roy Phillips indicating that Selective would have definitely issued the policy
  had it been submitted correctly to include automobile coverage. Â Insurance
  Associates also submitted a set of guidelines related to the â€œone and doneâ€
  computer software program that allowed â€œagentsâ€ to automatically secure
  policies if certain criteria are met.Â  In response, Selective submitted
  guidelines produced by Insurance Associates during discovery showing that a
  policy would not automatically be secured unless the underlying policy was also
  issued by Selective.Â  In this case, the underlying policy was not issued by
  Selective, but by Auto-Owners.Â  
We
  conclude the competing sets of guidelines raise a genuine issue of material
  fact precluding summary judgment.Â  Further inquiry into the facts may show
  Selective would not have issued the policy without the automobile exclusion.Â 
  If so, Selectiveâ€™s claim for indemnification as to the one and one-half million
  dollar settlement may prove viable.Â  If Selective cannot produce such evidence,
  the claim will likely fail.Â  However, we find the issue presented was too
  uncertain at this stage for the grant of summary judgment to be appropriate.
Finally,
  Insurance Associates contends Selective failed to mitigate its damages, barring
  its indemnification claim, by entering into the global settlement and not litigating
  coverage under the commercial umbrella policy.Â  We disagree.Â  
While
  Selective may have a viable coverage defense as to the Hunterâ€™s professional
  negligence claim, that defense was not a certainty.Â  Had they not settled,
  Selective could have been found responsible for the full four million dollars
  contemplated under the policy.Â  By settling, Selective made a calculated
  decision to minimize its own risk.Â  Furthermore, this mitigated the potential
  damages Selective can seek via indemnification from Insurance Associates.Â  
CONCLUSION
We
  are persuaded settlements like the one in this case are favorable, so long as
  the risk of collusion is minimized.Â  Therefore, we conclude the grant of
  summary judgment in favor of Insurance Associates should be reversed.Â 
  Furthermore, we believe the existence of the competing guidelines created a
  genuine issue of fact regarding Selectiveâ€™s claim for indemnification making
  the grant of summary judgment inappropriate.Â  Consequently, the decision of the circuit court is 
REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., and
  SHORT, J., concur.


[1] The Fowlers and
  Selective argued to the circuit court if a judgment in excess of the policy
  limits was required prior to determining the summary judgment motions, the
  motion hearing should be stayed and the underlying tort claim tried.Â  However,
  the circuit court elected to proceed with ruling on summary judgment motions.
[2] The overall
  settlement received was four and one-half million dollars.Â  However, as
  discussed further below, Selective contends one and one-half million dollars of
  the settlement was not payment from any particular policy.

title: State v. Nelson
description: In this criminal case, the Court of Appeals affirms the trial court's decision to admit an accomplice's written statement regarding the details of the crime into evidence.  The Court found the statement satisfied the requirements of Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE, and State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121-22, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001), such that its admission was proper.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Donnie Raymond
          Nelson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4423
  Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 8,
2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Kathrine H. Hudgins, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Julie M. Thames, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert Mills Ariail,
          of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: In this criminal case, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit into
  evidence the statement of Jarvis Clement (Clement).Â  
FACTS
Donnie
  Nelson (Nelson), along with two co-defendants,[1] proceeded to trial on charges arising from the robbery of Grady Blassingameâ€™s
  barbershop.Â  Investigator Tammy Patton (Patton) learned Clement was involved in
  the robbery of another barbershop named the Distinguished Gentlemen.Â  Patton
  interviewed Clement regarding the robbery of the Distinguished Gentlemen.Â 
  During this interview, Clement revealed the details of the Blassingame robbery.Â  
According
  to Clement, the following occurred on the day of the Blassingame robbery.Â  Shortly
  after arriving at Nanuâ€™s house, Nanu drove Nelson, Clovis, and Clement to a
  location across the street from the Blassingame barbershop.Â  Nelson and Clovis exited the vehicle and entered the Blassingame barbershop while Nanu and Clement
  drove around the block multiple times.Â  After the robbery, the four men
  returned to Clovisâ€™ house.Â  
The
  State moved to introduce into evidence Clementâ€™s written statement obtained by
  Patton.Â  Nelson, along with the other co-defendants, objected.Â  The trial court
  allowed the statement into evidence.Â  Nelson was found guilty of one count of
  armed robbery, two counts of possession of a weapon during the commission of a
  violent crime, and one count of conspiracy to commit armed robbery.Â  Nelson was
  sentenced to seventeen years imprisonment for the armed robbery charge, five
  years imprisonment for the weapon charges, and five years imprisonment for the
  conspiracy charge, all sentences to run concurrently.Â  This appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State
  v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  An appellate court
  is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.Â  The admission of evidence is
  within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Pittman, 373
  S.C. 527, 577, 647 S.E.2d 144, 170 (2007).Â  To constitute an abuse of
  discretion, the conclusions of the trial court must lack evidentiary support or
  be controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Nelson argues the
  trial court erroneously relied on Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE, in admitting Clementâ€™s
  written statement.[2]Â  We
  disagree.Â  
Pursuant
  to Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE, a statement is not hearsay if

  [t]he
    declarant testifies at the trial or hearing and is subject to cross-examination
    concerning the statement, and the statement is . . . consistent with the
    declarantâ€™s testimony and is offered to rebut an express or implied charge
    against the declarant of recent fabrication or improper influence or motive;
    provided, however, the statement must have been made before the alleged
    fabrication, or before the alleged improper influence or motive arose . . . .

The
  South Carolina Supreme Court has explained the following elements must be
  satisfied before a prior consistent statement can be admitted into evidence
  based upon Rule 801(d)(1)(B):

  (1) the declarant must testify and be
    subject to cross-examination, (2) the opposing party must have explicitly or
    implicitly accused the declarant of recently fabricating the statement or of
    acting under an improper influence or motive, (3) the statement must be consistent with
    the declarantâ€™s testimony, and (4)
    the statement must have been made prior to the alleged fabrication, or prior to
    the existence of the alleged improper influence or motive.

State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 121-22, 551 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2001). 
Before
  we address these elements, we must first determine whether Clement is the
  declarant.Â  We find Clement is the declarant because he made oral statements
  intended to be assertions.Â  Rule 801(a), (b), SCRE (explaining that a statement
  is an oral or written assertion intended to be an assertion and an individual
  who makes a statement is a declarant).Â  With this is mind, we now turn our
  attention to the elements set out in Saltz.
It
  is undisputed that Clement testified and was subject to cross-examination; thus,
  the first Saltz element is satisfied.Â  With respect to the second
  element, opposing counsel implicitly accused Clement of acting under an
  improper motive or influence by accusing Clement of lying in order to gain
  favorable sentencing.Â  Specifically, at the time of his interview, Clement was
  incarcerated for a forgery charge.Â  As noted above, Clement was involved in the robbery of the Distinguished
  Gentlemen.Â  Patton became aware of
  Clement through Clementâ€™s accomplice in the robbery of the Distinguished
  Gentlemen.Â  Patton
  interviewed Clement regarding the Distinguished
  Gentlemen.Â  During
  this interview, Clement revealed the details of the Blassingame robbery.Â  
As a result of his involvement in the two robberies, Clement was
  at minimum facing the following charges: two armed robberies, two kidnappings,
  conspiracy, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent
  crime.Â  At the time of the trial, Clement had been sentenced on the conspiracy charge
  and the possession charge, but he was still awaiting sentencing on the
  remaining charges.Â  Counsel for the defense repeatedly accused Clement of being
  untruthful in order to gain a more lenient sentence for the remaining charges.Â 
  Thus, the second Saltz element is fulfilled. 
The
  third element requires Clementâ€™s written statement be consistent with his trial
  testimony.Â  This element is also met.Â  In his written statement, Clement stated
  on the day of the Blassingame
  robbery he went to Nanuâ€™s house and saw Nelson there.Â  Clement also stated Nanu
  drove the four-member party to a location across the street from the Blassingame
  barbershop, Nelson and Clovis were dropped off and entered the barbershop, and
  Nanu drove repeatedly around the block until Nelson and Clovis exited the
  barbershop and entered Nanuâ€™s car at the location where they originally exited
  the vehicle.Â  Clement repeated this account during his testimony.Â  
Although it is true during trial Clement did not remember a few of
  the statements he made to Patton, we recognize two years passed between
  Clementâ€™s statement to Patton and the trial.Â  The trial occurred on January 18,
  2006, and Clement gave his statement to Patton on January 3, 2004.Â  We
  acknowledge it could be difficult for Clement to recollect every detail due to this
  two year time interval.Â  Additionally, viewing Clementâ€™s statement and his testimony
  as a whole, we conclude his statement is consistent with his testimony.Â  
The final element that must be met is the statement must have been made prior to
  the alleged fabrication or prior to the existence of the alleged improper
  influence or motive.Â  Saltz, 346 S.C. at 121-22, 551 S.E.2d
  at 244.Â  Nelson argues the statement to Patton was made after the existence of
  a motive to fabricate, namely in the hopes of receiving a lenient sentence.Â  We
  disagree.Â  
Even
  if we were to assume, without deciding, that Clement had an improper motive for
  fabricating the truth, this motive did not arise until after the statement was
  made.Â  As explained above, at the time of his interview, Clement was
  incarcerated for a forgery charge.Â  Clement volunteered the information concerning the robberies of the
  Distinguished Gentlemen and the Blassingame barbershop during an interview with Patton. Â The record is devoid of any evidence that
  Patton made any offers of leniency in order to induce Clement to make the
  statement.Â  State v. Serrette, 375 S.C. 650, 652, 654 S.E.2d 554, 555
  (Ct. App. 2007) (stating the burden is on the appellant to provide an appellate
  court with an adequate record for review); see Rule 210(h), SCACR (stating
  an appellate court need not consider any fact which does not appear in the record).Â 
  Therefore, the final Saltz element is met, and the trial court properly
  admitted the evidence based on Rule 801(d)(1)(B).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.[3]
THOMAS
and PIEPER, JJ., concur.


[1] The names of the co-defendants are Lawrence Waller,
also known as Nanu (Nanu), and Lawrence Clovis (Clovis).Â  
[2] The State argues this issue is not preserved for
  review. We disagree.Â  An objection was raised regarding the admissibility of
  Clementâ€™s written statement, and the trial court allowed the statement into
  evidence based on Rule 801(d), SCRE.Â  See Wilder
    Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497
  S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (holding for an issue to be preserved for appeal it must have
  been raised to and ruled upon by
the trial court).
[3] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Semken v. Semken
description: This is an appeal from the family court's order terminating the husband's obligation to pay alimony pursuant to the continued cohabitation provision of section 20-3-130(B)(1) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).  The family court applied the ordinary meaning of the word "reside" to the definition of "continued cohabitation" and found the wife and her boyfriend resided together for the required period of time during their relationship.  Following the family court's order, the Supreme Court issued Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 89, 650 S.E.2d 465, 472 (2007), wherein the Supreme Court stated that "continued cohabitation" requires the spouse receiving alimony to "live under the same roof as the person with whom they are romantically involved for at least ninety consecutive days."  Applying this interpretation to the wife's relationship, the Court of Appeals found the wife and her boyfriend did not continuously cohabitate for ninety or more consecutive days, and therefore, reversed the family court's order terminating the husband's alimony obligation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Francis M.
          Semken, Respondent,
        v.
        Catherine A.
          Semken, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Wayne M. Creech, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4424
Heard June 3, 2008 â€“ Filed July 8, 2008Â Â Â  

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
        J. Mark Taylor, of W. Columbia, Jane Nussbaum Douglas and Natalie
          P. Bluestein, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Gregory A. DeLuca, of Goose Creek, J. MichaelÂ  Taylor, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  In this family law action, Catherine Semken (Wife) appeals the
  family courtâ€™s order terminating Francis Semkenâ€™s (Husband) obligation to pay
  Wife alimony, awarding Husband reimbursement alimony, and requiring Wife to pay
  Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife divorced in 1999.Â 
  Pursuant to the final order, Husband was required to pay Wife permanent
  periodic alimony in the amount of $1,000 per month.Â  In 2005, Husband brought an
  action to have his alimony obligation terminated pursuant to the continued
  cohabitation provision of section 20-3-130(B)(1) of the South Carolina Code
  (Supp. 2007), claiming Wife and Thomas McGill (Boyfriend) had engaged in a
  romantic relationship and resided together for a period of more than ninety
  consecutive days. Â Wife and Boyfriend did not deny the romantic relationship,
  but both disputed the claim of cohabitation.Â  Â Â 
In support of Husbandâ€™s assertion, he presented evidence to show Wife
  rented a house owned by Boyfriend in Berkeley County, South Carolina from
  January 2002 through July 2005.Â  During this period, Boyfriend lived in
  separate residences in other counties in the state.Â  Wife and Boyfriend
  acknowledged they were involved in a romantic relationship during this time
  period, and it was likely that over the course of their three-year relationship
  the couple spent more than ninety non-consecutive days together in the Berkeley County residence.Â Â Â  
Although Wife paid Boyfriend $500 per month in rent, Wife and
  Boyfriend never entered into a written lease agreement.Â  Boyfriendâ€™s mortgage
  payment on the residence during this time period ranged from $550 to $625 per
  month, but in exchange for the lesser rent, Wife did not have full access to the
  house.Â  Boyfriend stored some of his belongings in one of the bedrooms of the
  house and kept a car in the garage.Â Â Â  
When Wife began renting the Berkeley County residence from
  Boyfriend, she transferred all the utility bills into her name and made all of
  the payments.Â  Boyfriend did not pay any of Wifeâ€™s expenses or help her
  financially, although he would occasionally allow Wife to pay rent late or in
  installments.Â  Boyfriend continued to pay insurance on the Berkeley County residence and its contents while Wife resided there, and he never changed the
  status on his homeownerâ€™s insurance policy from owner-occupied to
  rental-property.Â  Wife did not have any insurance on her belongings in the
  residence. 
 When
  Wife moved into the Berkeley County residence, Boyfriend moved to North Augusta due to his employment.Â  Boyfriend obtained a new driverâ€™s license reflecting
  his North Augusta address, and he registered to vote in Aiken County, South Carolina.Â  However, when Boyfriend later renewed his vehicle tag, he used the Berkeley County residence address and, pursuant to the â€œMotor Voterâ€ system, his voter
  registration was automatically reinstated in Berkeley County.Â Â Â Â  
After a
  year in North Augusta, Boyfriend moved to Newberry County and began operating a
  business out of this residence.Â  Subsequently, Boyfriend moved to Lexington County, which is where Boyfriend was living at the time he and Wife ended their
  romantic relationship.Â  Following their break-up, Boyfriend allowed Wife to
  stay in the Berkeley County residence rent-free for the three months prior to
  her moving out because she lost her job and could not afford to pay rent.Â  
Upon hearing the evidence, the family court found Husband had
  carried his burden of proof to show Wife and Boyfriend engaged in continued
  cohabitation for more than ninety days pursuant to Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1). Â The
  family court interpreted Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1) by applying the ordinary meaning to
  the word â€œresideâ€ and found during their romantic relationship, Boyfriend
  maintained two residences, one of which was the Berkeley County residence.Â  The
  family court stated, â€œIt is clear that [Boyfriend] has not spent every night
  and day for [more] than 90 consecutive days with [Wife] at the Berkeley County home address but that is not what the statute requires.Â  The statute only
  requires that [Boyfriend] â€˜resideâ€™ there at the same time with [Wife].â€Â  The
  family court further found despite Wife and Boyfriend not spending more than
  ninety consecutive days and nights under the same roof, â€œthey both claimed the Berkeley County home as a residence at the same time, spent a considerable amount of time
  together, were romantically involved, and claimed the same home as a residence.â€Â 
  The family court additionally stated, â€œIt is critical to this decision to note
  that if [Wife] had moved into an apartment owned by someone else (or even an
  identified rental property owned by [Boyfriend]) rather than one of
  [Boyfriendâ€™s] â€˜residences,â€™ there would have been a different outcome.â€Â  Â Â Â 
Based
  on these findings, the family court terminated Husbandâ€™s obligation to pay Wife
  alimony.Â  The family court further ordered Wife to reimburse Husband for
  the alimony payments made from November 2005 through July 2006.Â  Additionally,
  the family court required Wife to pay $10,000 towards Husbandâ€™s attorneyâ€™s
  fees.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œOn
  appeal from the family court, this [C]ourt has jurisdiction to correct errors
  of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of
  the evidence.â€Â  Henggeler v. Hanson, 333 S.C. 598, 601-02, 510 S.E.2d
  722, 724 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  A preponderance of the evidence stated simply is
  that evidence which convinces as to its truth.Â  Frazier v. Frazier, 228
  S.C. 149, 168, 89 S.E.2d 225, 235 (1955). Despite this broad scope of review,
  this Court is not required to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Doe v.
    Roe, 369 S.C. 351, 359, 631 S.E.2d 317, 321 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  This Court
  remains mindful the family court saw and heard the witnesses, placing it in a
  better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to
  their testimony.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
  

I. Termination of Alimony
  Pursuant to Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1)
Wife begins by
  arguing the family court erred in finding Wife engaged in continued
  cohabitation with Boyfriend and, therefore, erred in terminating alimony.Â  We
  agree.Â  
Section
  20-3-130(B)(1) allows for the termination of periodic alimony upon â€œthe
  remarriage or continued cohabitation of the supported spouse . . . .â€Â  The statute
  states:

  For
    purposes of this subsection and unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
    parties, â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ means the supported spouse resides with
    another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety or more
    consecutive days.Â  The court may determine that a continued cohabitation exists
    if there is evidence that the supported spouse resides with another person in a
    romantic relationship for periods of less than ninety days and the two
    periodically separate in order to circumvent the ninety-day requirement.Â  

Â§
  20-3-130(B).Â  
The South Carolina
  Supreme Court recently addressed the issue of terminating a husbandâ€™s alimony
  obligation due to the wifeâ€™s continued cohabitation with another man pursuant
  to section 20-3-150 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007).Â  Section 20-3-150
  calls for any award of alimony to the spouse retaining custody of the coupleâ€™s
  children to cease upon the remarriage or continued cohabitation of the
  supported spouse.Â  Section 20-3-150 further states:

  For
    purposes of this subsection and unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
    parties, â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ means the supported spouse resides with
    another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety or more
    consecutive days.Â  The court may determine that a continued cohabitation exists
    if there is evidence that the supported spouse resides with another person in a
    romantic relationship for periods of less than ninety days and the two
    periodically separate in order to circumvent the ninety-day requirement.Â  

When interpreting
  this language, the South Carolina Supreme Court found â€œthe phrase â€˜resides
  withâ€™ . . . sets forth a requirement that the supported spouse live under
    the same roof as the person with whom they are romantically involved for at
  least ninety consecutive days.â€Â  Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76,
  89, 650 S.E.2d 465, 472 (2007) (emphasis added).Â  The Supreme Court reasoned
  that â€œ[a]ny other interpretation essentially takes the â€˜cohabitationâ€™ out of
  â€˜continued cohabitation.â€™â€Â  Id.
The
  statute in question in the current case, Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1), contains the same
  language as Â§ 20-3-150 defining â€œcontinued cohabitation.â€Â  Thus, the Supreme
  Courtâ€™s interpretation of that language controls this Courtâ€™s determination of
  whether Wife and Boyfriend engaged in continued cohabitation for ninety or more
  consecutive days.Â  
 In the case at
  hand, the family court addressed the meaning of â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ prior
  to the Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Strickland, focusing on the definition
  of â€œresidence.â€Â  The family court stated it was applying the ordinary meaning
  of the word â€œresideâ€ to the statute.Â Â Â  Â 
Applying
  this interpretation to Wife and Boyfriendâ€™s situation, the family court found
  Boyfriend â€œmaintained two residencesâ€ during their relationship, one of which
  was the Berkeley County home where Wife resided.Â  The family court stated, â€œIt
  is clear that [Boyfriend] has not spent every night and day for [more] than 90
  consecutive days with [Wife] at the Berkeley County home address but that is
  not what the statute requires.Â  The statute only requires that [Boyfriend]
  â€˜resideâ€™ at the same time with [Wife].â€ Â The family court further emphasized
  this interpretation by stating, 

  [E]ven
    though [Wife] and [Boyfriend] did not spend more than 90 consecutive days and
    nights under the same roof, it is clear that they both claimed the Berkeley
    County home as a residence at the same time . . . .Â  It is critical to this
    decision to note that if [Wife] had moved into an apartment owned by someone
    else (or even an identified rental property owned by [Boyfriend]) rather than
    one of [Boyfriendâ€™s] â€œresidences,â€ there would have been a different outcome.Â  Â Â Â Â 

The
  Supreme Court applied a meaning to the phrase â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ that requires
  the spouse and the paramour to actually â€œlive under the same roofâ€ for ninety
  consecutive days, rather then merely claim the same residence for that time
  period.Â  Strickland, 375 S.C. at 89, 650 S.E.2d at 472. Â The family
  court specifically found Wife and Boyfriend did not live under the same roof
  for ninety consecutive days.Â  Further, the family court made no findings that
  Wife and Boyfriend periodically separated in order to circumvent the ninety-day
  requirement, and the facts do not warrant such a finding.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The
  evidence demonstrates Wife and Boyfriend were romantically involved but did not
  engage in continued cohabitation, as defined by Strickland, during their
  relationship.Â  The evidence shows Boyfriend did not live in under the same roof
  as Wife for ninety consecutive days.Â  Pursuant to Strickland, Husband
  has not proven that Wifeâ€™s relationship with Boyfriend amounts to â€œcontinued
  cohabitationâ€ under Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1). Â We, therefore, reverse the family
  courtâ€™s termination of alimony and reinstate Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation.Â  
Because
  we find Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation was incorrectly terminated, Wife must be
  restored to the position she was in before the family courtâ€™s judgment was
  rendered.Â  See Brown v. Brown, 286 S.C. 56, 57, 331 S.E.2d 793,
  793-94 (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œGenerally, reversal of a judgment on appeal has the
  effect of vacating the judgment and leaving the case standing as if no such
  judgment had been rendered.â€).Â  â€œ[W]hen a judgment reducing support payments is
  reversed on appeal, the parties are placed in the same position as if no
  reduction had been ordered and the supporting spouse is liable for arrearages
  from the date of the reduction to the date of reversal.â€Â  Id. at 57-58,
  331 S.E.2d at 794.Â  Husband is, therefore, liable for any amount of alimony he
  did not pay as a consequence of the family courtâ€™s ruling.Â  We remand the issue
  of arrearages to the family court for a determination of the monetary amount owed
  to Wife, as well as a determination of an appropriate payment schedule for
  Husband to follow.Â  
II. Termination of Alimony
  Pursuant to Additional Sustaining Ground
Husband argues even
  if this Court finds the statutory requirements of Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1) have not
  been satisfied, an alternate sustaining ground exists to terminate Husbandâ€™s
  alimony obligation.Â  Husband specifically argues Wifeâ€™s relationship with
  Boyfriend was tantamount to marriage, warranting a termination of alimony due
  to a change in Wifeâ€™s circumstances.Â  We decline to address this issue.Â  
As the prevailing
  party in the family court, a respondent may raise an additional sustaining
  ground for this Court to consider.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).Â  This Court, however, may
  ignore any such arguments, especially if the additional ground was not
  presented to the family court.Â  Id. at 421, 526 S.E.2d at 724. Â â€œ[T]he
  current rules do not impose any presentation requirement.Â  However, the failure
  to present an additional sustaining ground to the [family] court reduces the
  likelihood an appellate court will rely on it to affirm a judgment.â€Â  Id. at 421 n.11, 526 S.E.2d at 724 n.11.Â  
 In the family
  court, Husband stated he sought to have his alimony obligation terminated based
  solely on the statutory ground found in Â§ 20-3-130(B)(1).Â  The parties never
  mentioned or discussed terminating alimony based on the common law argument of
  Wifeâ€™s relationship with Boyfriend being tantamount to marriage.Â  This argument
  is being raised for the first time in this appeal.Â  Although South Carolina
  court rules allow Husband as the prevailing party to initially raise this
  additional sustaining ground in his appeal, we decline to rely on this ground
  as a means of affirming the family courtâ€™s order, as we find it would be unfair
  to Wife because this argument was not presented to the family court. Â Â Â 
III.
  Reimbursement of Alimony
Because
  we find alimony should not be terminated, Wife must be restored to the position
  she was in before the family courtâ€™s judgment was rendered.Â  See Brown,
  286 S.C. at 57, 331 S.E.2d at 793-94 (â€œGenerally, reversal of a judgment on
  appeal has the effect of vacating the judgment and leaving the case standing as
  if no such judgment had been rendered.â€).Â  Consequently, Wife should not be
  ordered to reimburse Husband for any alimony payments made while the action was
  pending.[1]Â 
  Therefore, consistent with this opinion, we reverse the family courtâ€™s order
  for reimbursement.Â Â  
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees 
Finally, Wife
  argues the family court erred in ordering her to contribute to Husbandâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife also argues the family court erred in failing to order
  Husband to contribute towards her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In light of our decision to
  reverse the family courtâ€™s termination of Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation, we
  similarly reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and remand the issue for
  reconsideration.Â  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427
  S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993) (reversing and remanding issue of attorneyâ€™s fees for
  reconsideration when the substantive results achieved by trial counsel were
  reversed on appeal).
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
REVERSED and
  REMANDED.
THOMAS and
PIEPER, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] After terminating Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation, the
  family court ordered Wife to reimburse Husband for alimony payments made from
November 15, 2005, through July 15, 2006, which totaled $9,450.Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      E. Chandler McNair, Respondent,
      v.
      Fairfield County, Appellant.
    
  


Appeal from Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4425
  Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 8,
2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Clifford O. Koon and Paul D. de Holczer,
          of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Thomas H. Pope, III, of Newberry, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN,
  C.J.:Â  This appeal arises
  out of Fairfield Countyâ€™s attempt to condemn private property owned by E.
  Chandler McNair.Â  McNair filed a complaint challenging the Countyâ€™s right to
  condemn the property, and after receiving inadequate responses to his requests
  for discovery, McNair moved for sanctions.Â  The trial court granted the motion,
  struck the Countyâ€™s answer, and dismissed the condemnation action with
  prejudice.Â  The County appeals, and we affirm. 
FACTS
In September of 2005, Fairfield County served a condemnation notice on McNair, informing him the County intended to
  condemn a tract of land he owned adjacent to the Fairfield County Airport.Â  Purportedly, the taking was necessary to extend one of the runways at the
  airport so it could accommodate large, commercial airplanes.Â  McNair challenged
  the condemnation, and in November of 2005, McNair sent the County discovery
  requests.Â  On February 10, 2006, the County produced over 800 documents of
  discovery.Â  Two weeks later, McNair filed a motion to compel, alleging the
  County failed to produce certain documents, had not coherently organized the
  documents it did produce, and had provided incomplete responses to his
  interrogatories.Â  
The trial court issued an order on April 20, 2006, finding the
  County failed to respond to McNairâ€™s First Request for Production and that the
  Countyâ€™s responses to Plaintiffâ€™s First Set of Interrogatories was deficient.Â 
  The court did not impose any sanctions but ordered the County to correct its
  discovery responses within fifteen days. 
Despite this directive from the trial court, the County made no
  attempt to correct the deficiencies in its discovery responses.Â  McNairâ€™s
  counsel wrote six letters requesting the County comply with the order, and
  finally moved for dismissal and/or sanctions against the County on October 16,
  2006, six months after the order compelling discovery had been issued. 
A hearing on the motion was convened on November 15, and upon the
  promise of the Countyâ€™s attorney to have the discovery problems resolved within
  a month, the hearing was continued until December.Â  At the December hearing,
  with no progress made toward correcting the discovery issues, the Countyâ€™s
  attorney explained its noncompliance with the discovery order was because of a
  funding deadline imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration (the FAA).Â 
  Apparently, the FAA intended to have substantial progress completed on the
  runway extension project by October of 2006, and because that had not occurred,
  the FAA was threatening to withdraw funding for the project.Â  With funding for
  the project in jeopardy, the County was wary of spending additional money to
  litigate the condemnation challenge.Â  Counsel for the County urged the trial
  court to allow him to prepare a scheduling order rather than striking the
  answer. Counsel explained such an order would aid him in his negotiations with
  the FAA.Â  The trial court warned it was inclined to strike the answer, but in
  hopes of resolving the problem amicably, granted the parties forty-five days
  â€œto reach some kind of an accord,â€ and if they could not, to submit proposed
  orders within that time.Â  
On the forty-fifth day after the December hearing, the trial
  court, having never received a proposed order from the County, issued an order
  striking the Countyâ€™s answer to the condemnation challenge and dismissing with
  prejudice the Countyâ€™s condemnation action. Four days later, on February 6,
  2007, the County submitted a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion along with a proposed
  scheduling order.Â  In its motion, the County asked the court to reconsider the
  order striking the Countyâ€™s answer in light of the belated scheduling order.Â  
Â At the hearing on the Countyâ€™s motion, McNair presented a letter
  from the FAA dated February 5, 2007, which indicated the FAA intended to
  withdraw its funding for the Fairfield County Airport runway extension project
  unless the land acquisition portion of the project was completed within ninety
  days.Â  The County admitted it would not be able to resolve the challenge action
  within the time parameters imposed by the FAA.[1]Â  
The trial court found no basis for reconsidering its previous
  order. The court also noted its decision to strike the answer and dismiss the
  condemnation action would not have changed even if Fairfield County had timely submitted the proposed scheduling order.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under
  Rule 37(b)(2)(C), SCRCP, when a party fails to comply with a discovery order,
  the trial court has the discretion to impose a sanction it deems just,
  including an order dismissing the action.Â  Barnette v. Adams Bros. Logging,
    Inc., 355 S.C. 588, 593, 586 S.E.2d 572, 575 (2003). Â Absent an abuse of
  discretion, the trial courtâ€™s imposition of discovery sanctions will not be
  reversed on appeal, and the party appealing from the order of sanction carries
  the burden of proving an abuse of discretion occurred.Â  Id. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Fairfield County argues the trial court erred by granting McNairâ€™s motion for sanctions and
  denying its Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion.Â  We disagree.
Initially, the
  County argues the trial court abused its discretion by signing McNairâ€™s
  proposed order forty-six minutes before the close of business on the day the
  proposed orders were due, without first reviewing the Countyâ€™s proposed
  scheduling order.Â  This argument has no merit for two reasons.Â  First, the
  County failed to timely submit a scheduling order, so even if the trial court had
  waited until 5:00 p.m., it still would not have had the benefit of a proposed order
  from the County.Â  Second, in the courtâ€™s order denying the countyâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion,
  the court took the scheduling order into consideration and adhered to its
  initial order.Â Â  Because waiting until the close of business before issuing its
  order would not have made a difference, the trial court did not abuse its
  discretion by issuing its order before the time for presenting a proposed order
  had elapsed.Â  See McCall v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26,
  28 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œ[W]hatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t matter.â€).
County also argues
  the trial court abused its discretion because striking the Countyâ€™s answer was
  unreasonably harsh under the circumstances.Â  We disagree.
As stated above,
  sanctions for discovery abuse are left to the sound discretion of the trial
  court.Â  See Barnette, 355 S.C. at 593, 586 S.E.2d at 575. However,
  severe sanctions, such as the dismissal of an action, should only be imposed in
  cases involving bad faith, willful disobedience, or gross indifference to the
  opposing partyâ€™s rights.Â  See Orlando v. Boyd, 320 S.C.
  509, 511, 466 S.E.2d 353, 355 (1996); Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co.,
  306 S.C. 101, 108-09, 410 S.E.2d 537, 541-42 (1991); Griffin Grading &
    Clearing, Inc. v. Tire Serv. Equip. Mfg. Co., 334 S.C. 193, 198-99, 511
  S.E.2d 716, 719 (Ct. App. 1999).
After deciding to
  strike the Countyâ€™s answer, the trial court noted:

  [T]he
    defense still has not produced documents 7 Â½ months after this Court passed an
    Order granting plaintiffâ€™s motion to compel.Â  The delay caused by defendant is
    a further prejudice to plaintiffâ€™s right to have his claim heard. Â . . . 
  The
    defendant is to blame for this unconscionable delay, and the defendantâ€™s
    conduct amounts to contempt.Â  This Court has considered whether a sanction less
    than striking the Answer in this case would achieve justice, and this Court
    concludes not.Â  . . . 
  The
    defendantâ€™s conduct in refusing to provide that which it has been ordered to
    produce is a serious affront to the integrity of the judicial system.Â  . . .Â 
    The defendantâ€™s failure to make any attempt to comply with the court order
    compelling discovery is a blatant violation of Rule 37(b)(2), SCRCP.

 In addition to the
  explicit findings above, we note the trial court warned the County during the
  December hearing it was inclined to strike the Countyâ€™s Answer.Â  Despite this
  warning, the County failed to submit a proposed scheduling order within
  forty-five days.Â  Furthermore, at the reconsideration hearing, the County was
  no closer to resolving the funding issues than it had been a year before, when
  the order compelling discovery had been issued.
â€œIn
  determining the appropriateness of a sanction, the court should consider such
  factors as the precise nature of the discovery and the discovery posture of the
  case, willfulness, and degree of prejudice.â€ Â Griffin Grading &
    Clearing, Inc., 334 S.C. at 199, 511 S.E.2d at 719. Here, the trial court considered
  the appropriate factors, and determined the Countyâ€™s willful disobedience of
  previous orders warranted the severe sanction of dismissal.Â  
CONCLUSION
Although we
  recognize the penalty is harsh, we find the trial court did not abuse its
  discretion in striking the Countyâ€™s answer and dismissing the condemnation
  action.Â  To the extent Fairfield County raises additional arguments in its
  brief,[2] we find they are not preserved for our review because they were never raised to
  or ruled upon by the trial court.Â  
Accordingly,
  the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.[3] 
KONDUROS, J.,
and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  


[1] Based upon memoranda submitted by counsel following
this courtâ€™s inquiry, this matter is not moot. 
[2] Specifically, the following arguments were never
  raised to the trial court: (1) the order contained internal inconsistencies
  regarding the reason the Countyâ€™s conduct constituted discovery abuse; (2) the
  trial court abused its discretion by failing to hold a factual hearing before
  dismissing the condemnation action; (3) the trial court erred by failing to
  hold a hearing before concluding the County had no public purpose, benefit, or
  use in condemning the land; (4) the trial court abused its discretion in
  dismissing the condemnation action because this â€œarguablyâ€ forecloses the
  County from ever improving its County Airport; (5) the trial court abused its
  discretion by finding the County in contempt without holding a factual hearing;
  (6) the trial courtâ€™s assumption that FAA funds would be withdrawn was not
  supported by competent evidence; and (7) the trial courtâ€™s finding that the
  County refused to produce voluminous documents was not supported by competent
evidence.
[3]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
to Rule 215, SCACR.

        Mozingo &

        v.
        Patricia Grand,

Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master In Equity

Opinion No. 4426

2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Henrietta U. Golding and Christopher L. Williams, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant-Respondent.
        David B. Miller, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  This case
  involves cross-appeals in a mechanicâ€™s lien action.Â  Patricia Grand argues the
  trial court erred in holding Mozingo & Wallace Architects complied with its
  obligations under the contract.Â  Patricia Grand also asserts the trial court
  erred in holding Mozingo & Wallace was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as the
  prevailing party and in failing to award it attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Mozingo &
  Wallace argues the trial court erred in limiting its award of attorneyâ€™s fees to

FACTS
In
  October of 2001, S. Derrick Mozingo, Jr., principal architect with Mozingo
  & Wallace, met with George B. Buchanan, Jr. and Benji Norton of Patricia
  Grand to discuss renovations to a hotel now known as Monterey Bay.Â  Buchanan expressed his admiration of two of Mozingo & Wallaceâ€™s similar projects.Â  He
  indicated he wanted a â€œSouth Floridaâ€ look for the hotel.Â  Although Mozingo
  asked Buchanan what his budget was for the project, Buchanan did not have an
  answer for him. 
The parties
  subsequently entered into a contract for Mozingo & Wallace to perform the
  schematic design work for the exterior of the building.Â  Although Mozingo
  stated in the cover letter for the contract that the submittals and approvals
  would be ready no later than the third week of November, the parties did not
  meet until December 12.Â  At that meeting Mozingo presented two designs for the
  project, a â€œModernâ€ theme and a â€œMediterraneanâ€ theme.Â  During the meeting
  Buchanan also requested Mozingo design a renovation of the lobby and laundry
  facility.Â  In his follow-up letter dated December 13, 2001, Mozingo noted the
  parties had agreed to move forward on the development of the â€œMediterraneanâ€ theme
  and the interior work.Â  He explained Mozingo & Wallace would not be able to
  commence work on the exterior and interior projects until after the first of
  the year.Â  In addition, he stated the work presented at the meeting completed
  the work under the original contract agreement. Â The next day Mozingo &
  Wallace sent Patricia Grand an invoice for the services to date.Â  The work on
  the interior renovation was invoiced as an additional expense at the
  contractual hourly rates.Â  Mozingo & Wallace also enclosed a contract for
  the balance of the work on the interior and exterior renovations.Â  The contract
  included a work schedule for the renovations.Â  Patricia Grand never executed
  this contract.Â  
In a letter dated
  December 27, 2001, Buchannan wrote Mozingo that he had not approved the design
  and that approval would depend on obtaining acceptable cost parameters and
  permission from the city for the improvements.Â  He listed six changes he felt
  should be considered.Â  In a reply letter, Mozingo stated he had no problem with
  the requested changes but would need to review the items with Buchanan.Â  At
  Buchananâ€™s insistence, Mozingo submitted the schematics of the exterior renovation
  to a contractor for an estimate.Â  The contractor, however, indicated there was
  not enough detailed information to provide a ballpark figure.Â  
In a
  letter dated January 11, 2002, Buchanan expressed his concern that the projects
  were getting behind and it might not be feasible to complete them that spring.Â 
  In response, Mozingo sent him schedules for the interior and exterior
  renovations.Â  On January 15, Buchanan ordered Mozingo by fax to put on hold
  work on the exterior renovation and they would consider the job for the
  following winter.Â  He also advised that he would hold off on a decision on the
  interior work until an opinion was obtained from the city regarding approval
  for the project.Â  Mozingo responded that he was concerned by the tone of
  Buchannanâ€™s note.Â  He explained he could have all submittals and approvals in
  place already but Buchanan had insisted on obtaining an estimate from a
  contractor before proceeding.Â  In addition, Mozingo stated that he never
  thought that construction on the exterior renovation could be competed before
  the summer season but he believed the work would have very little impact on the
  hotel guests.Â  However, he did assure Buchanan that the interior renovation
  could be accomplished before Memorial Day.Â  
In a letter dated
  February 11, 2002, Buchanan expressed his dissatisfaction over the exterior and
  interior renovations.Â  He stated he found both proposed plans for the exterior
  renovation to be impractical and that Mozingo had failed to deliver acceptable
  plans that could be completed during the slow months of January and February.Â 
  In addition, he noted he was unhappy with the delay with the interior
  renovation but wanted to continue on a fast-track basis.Â  He proposed to
  renegotiate the contract for the projects, including evenly allocating the
  $25,000 already paid between the two projects.Â  Mozingo took exception at the tone
  of the letter and terminated his services.Â  He demanded full payment of the
  invoice for services to date.Â  In return, Buchanan demanded a refund of
  $22,955.00.Â  
Mozingo &
  Wallace filed a notice and certificate of Mechanicâ€™s lien listing $14,173.47 as
  the amount due.Â  It subsequently brought this action seeking foreclosure of the
  lien, collection, and quantum meruit.Â  Patricia Grand denied Mozingo &
  Wallaceâ€™s entitlement to the relief sought and counterclaimed for breach of
  contract.Â  The trial court found in favor of Mozingo & Wallace and awarded
  it $24,563.81 for architectural fees and interest accrued at the 18% rate set
  forth in the contract.Â  In addition, the court awarded Mozingo & Wallace
  attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $17,975.57.Â  On Patricia Grandâ€™s motion to
  alter or amend, the court reduced the attorney fee award to $14,177.47, the
  amount stated in the notice and certificate of lien.Â  Both Patricia Grand and
  Mozingo & Wallace appealed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
  

An
  action to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien is an action at law.Â  Seckinger v.
    Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 386, 483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œIn
  an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of
  fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without
  evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs. v.
City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
  

1. Patricia Grandâ€™s appeal
Patricia
  Grand argues the trial court erred in finding Mozingo & Wallace complied
  with its obligations under the contract since it did not complete the scope of
  services required by the contract.Â  We disagree.Â  
A party who seeks
  to recover damages for breach of a contract must show that the contract has
  been performed on his part, or at least that he was, at the appropriate time,
  able, ready and willing to perform it.Â  Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 487, 514 S.E.2d 126, 135 (1999).Â  Patricia Grand
  first contends Mozingo & Wallace did not complete its preparation of the
  exterior design schematics as it never made the revisions requested by Patricia
  Grand.Â  After Buchanan requested Mozingo make six revisions to the schematics,
  Mozingo agreed to make the changes.Â  However, he admitted at trial that he
  never did in fact make the revisions.Â  Mozingo explained all of the changes
  Buchanan requested involved simply deleting certain things or changing or
  painting certain items.Â  He stated that he felt like all of the changes would
  be addressed or should be addressed in the second phase of the base contract.Â 
  Patricia Grand, however, ordered Mozingo & Wallace to stop work on the
  exterior renovation before it could progress to the second phase.Â  Thus,
  Patricia Grandâ€™s own acts prevented Mozingo & Wallace from completing the
  revision.Â  See Moon v. Jordan, 301 S.C. 161, 164, 390 S.E.2d 488,
  490 (Ct. App. 1990)Â  (â€œGenerally, if a party by his contract charges himself
  with an obligation possible to be performed, he must make it good unless its
  performance is rendered impossible by an act of God, the law, or other party.â€)Â 
  (emphasis added).Â  
Next Patricia Grand
  contends Mozingo & Wallace did not complete all the tasks required by the
  contract with respect to the Myrtle Beach Community Appearance Board (CAB).Â 
  The contractâ€™s â€œScope of Designated Servicesâ€ included CAB review submittals
  and approvals for the exterior project.Â  Mozingo testified he was ready to take
  the schematics for the exterior renovation to CAB for review but he was never
  given the directive to do such because of the indecision with the project.Â  He
  stated he needed both Patricia Grandâ€™s final approval of the conceptual design,
  as well as a current as-built survey from Patricia Grand before he could submit
  plans to CAB.Â  He received neither.Â  Thus, there is evidence in the record that
  Mozingo & Wallaceâ€™s failure to complete this aspect of the contract was due
  to Patricia Grandâ€™s acts.Â  
Finally, Patricia
  Grand asserts the conceptual design did not comply with relevant zoning
  ordinances.Â  Certain decorative items in the design may have protruded over the
  set-back limits set forth in the ordinance.Â  Mozingo testified that without a
  current as-built survey, which Patricia Grand never supplied, he was not exactly
  sure there would be a problem with the setbacks and he felt it was probably
  close to being within the allowed area.Â  He stated if the decorative items did
  protrude past the setback lines by a few inches, Patricia Grand would need a
  variance.Â  However, he stated he did not see obtaining a variance as a problem,
  just a process.Â  
We find the record
  provides evidence that Mozingo & Wallace fulfilled its responsibilities
  under the contract or was prevented from doing so by Patricia Grandâ€™s own
  acts.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial court allowing Mozingo &
  Wallace to recover under the contract.Â  
At oral argument,
  Patricia Grand asserted that under section 12.2.8 of the contract, it was
  entitled to equitable adjustment for the work Mozingo & Wallace failed to
  perform.Â  This issue is not properly before this court.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 250, 551
  S.E.2d 274, 278 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œAn appellant may not use oral argument as a
  vehicle to argue issues not argued in the appellantâ€™s brief.â€); Rule
  208(b)(1)(B), SCACR (â€œOrdinarily, no point will be considered which is not set
  forth in the statement of issues on appeal.â€).
Patricia
  Grand argues the trial court erred in awarding Mozingo & Wallace attorneyâ€™s
  fees because once Patricia Grand filed a surety bond, the lien was terminated
  and Mozingo & Wallace could not prevail in an action to terminate the
  lien.Â  This argument was never raised to or ruled on by the trial court.Â 
  Accordingly, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v.
    Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that
  an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate
  review.â€).Â  
Next
  Patricia Grand argues the trial court should have awarded it attorneyâ€™s fees
  rather than Mozingo & Wallace because Mozingo & Wallace cannot be the
  prevailing party as it failed to complete the tasks it agreed to perform.Â  As
  stated above, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Mozingo &
  Wallace was entitled to recover under the contract.Â  Therefore, we find no
  merit in Patricia Grandâ€™s argument regarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
2. Mozingo & Wallaceâ€™s appeal
Mozingo
  & Wallace argues the trial court erred in reducing the award of attorneyâ€™s
  fees to the principal debt recited in the notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s
  lien.Â  We disagree.
The
  mechanicâ€™s lien statute provides the prevailing party may recover reasonable
  attorneyâ€™s fees, â€œbut the fee and the court costs may not exceed the amount of
  the lien.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (a) (2007).Â  â€œThe primary rule of
  statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the
  legislature.â€Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington v. Altman, 324 S.C.
  65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  â€œ[T]he words of the statute must be given
  their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced
  construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€ Â Mun. Assâ€™n of
    S.C. v. AT & T Communications of S. States, 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606
  S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical,
  reasonable, and fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and
  policy of lawmakers.â€Â  TNS Mills v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611,
  624, 503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).
We hold the
  legislature intended to limit the award of fees and costs to the amount set
  forth in the notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  This limit on the
  amount of the award applies not only to a party prevailing in enforcing a lien
  but also to a party prevailing in defending the lien action.Â  It would not be
  reasonable for a party enforcing the lien to be able to recover higher
  attorneyâ€™s fees if it prevailed because it could add prejudgment interest to
  the lien award but limit a defending party if it prevailed to the debt stated
  in the notice and certificate of lien.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court
  properly reduced the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded to the amount of the
  debt set forth in the notice and certificate of lien.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial
  court did not err in allowing Mozingo & Wallace to recover under the
  contract.Â  As the prevailing party, Mozingo & Wallace was entitled to
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In addition, we hold the trial court correctly reduced the
  amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded to the amount of the debt stated in the
  notice and certificate of lien.Â  
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, JJ.,
and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â
