THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        M&M Group,
          Inc., Appellant,
        v.
        Suzette A. L.
          Holmes, Gregory M. Kopatch d/b/a Empire Business Brokers, Empire Business
          Brokerage, LLC, and Gregory M. Kopatch Individually, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No. 4427
  Submitted June 2, 2008 - Filed July 15,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William J. Cutchin, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Brian G. Burke, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

THOMAS, J.: In
  this breach of contract action, M&M Group, Inc. appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  grant of summary judgment to Suzette Holmes, Gregory M. Kopatch[1] d/b/a Empire Business Brokers, Empire Business Brokerage, LLC, and Gregory M.
  Kopatch.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
M&M Group, Inc. (â€œM&Mâ€) was the owner of a carwash and
  lube business located in Mt. Pleasant. Â Wishing to sell the business and its
  assets, M&M signed an exclusive Listing Agreement with Gregory Kopatch
  (Kopatch), a commercial sales broker doing business as Empire Business
  Brokerage, L.L.C. (Brokerage). Â Pursuant to the Listing Agreement, the
  Brokerage would sell the business and M&M would then pay a commission to
  the Brokerage.
Kopatch identified Suzette Holmes (â€œHolmesâ€) as a potential buyer,
  and on April 12, 2005, M&M and Holmes executed a sales contract
  (â€œContractâ€).Â  Under the terms of the Contract, M&M agreed to transfer its
  assets to Holmes in exchange for Holmesâ€™ payment of $675,000 to M&M. Â The
  first page of the Contract stated, â€œ[w]hereas, the parties agree that Buyerâ€™s
  obligation to purchase the assets of the business and Sellerâ€™s obligation to
  sell the assets is contingent upon Buyerâ€™s ability to secure commercial
  financing at prevailing interest rates.â€ Â The Contract provided that Holmes was
  to secure $225,000 of the purchase price through commercial financing and
  M&M was to finance $250,000 with a sixty-month promissory note.Â  The seven
  page Contract also set the closing date as May 22, 2005, and stated that time was
  of the essence.[3] 
On May 9, 2005, Holmesâ€™ request for a loan was denied. Â No
  closing occurred on May 22, 2005, and the sales transaction was never
  consummated thereafter.Â  An affidavit by M&Mâ€™s President, Sean Mummert, states
  the Brokerage called him on May 22 and told him a proposed lender needed
  additional information from Holmes before it would approve her financing
  request.Â  Mummert affirms he told the Brokerage he would grant Holmes an
  extension in order for her to obtain financing needed to complete the
  transaction.Â  No further communication occurred until October 12, 2005, when
  M&M received a letter informing them the proposed transaction was voided
  when Holmes was unable to obtain financing. Â A bank turndown letter
  regarding the May 9th denial of Holmesâ€™ loan request was also
  attached to the October 12th letter.
On November 14, 2005, M&M filed a complaint alleging breach of
  contract against Holmes as well as breach of fiduciary duty, breach of
  contract, and breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act against
  Kopatch and the Brokerage. Holmes subsequently filed a Motion for Summary
  Judgment which was heard by the trial court on March 16, 2007. Â Ruling from the
  bench, the trial court granted Holmesâ€™ summary judgment motion.Â  M&M now
  appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  reviewing an order for summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same
  standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56 of the South Carolina
  Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Town of Awendaw, 359 S.C. 29, 34, 596 S.E.2d 482, 485 (2004).  Summary judgment is
  appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and
  admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to
  a judgment as a matter of law.â€  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.  â€œOn appeal from
  an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all
  ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a
  light most favorable to the appellant, the non-moving party below.â€Â  Willis
    v. Wu, 362 S.C. 146, 151, 607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).Â  
â€œThe
  purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not
  require the services of a fact finder.â€ George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440,
  452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001). Â â€œA court considering summary judgment neither
  makes factual determinations nor considers the merits of competing testimony;
  however, summary judgment is completely appropriate when a properly supported
  motion sets forth facts that remain undisputed or are contested in a deficient
  manner.â€ David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 250, 626 S.E.2d
  1, 5 (2006). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
  

I. Motion for
  Summary Judgment
M&M
  contends the trial court erred by granting Holmes summary judgment in light of
  the fact that Holmesâ€™ motion failed to state with particularity the grounds for
  summary judgment.Â  We disagree.
Holmesâ€™
  motion for summary judgment stated, â€œ[t]he grounds for this motion shall be set forth in a
  Memorandum of Law to be timely filed with supporting documents and affidavits
  as required.â€Â  No such memorandum was filed with the trial court or provided to
  M&M.Â  At the summary judgment hearing, M&M objected to the hearing
  itself since Holmes failed to follow Rule 7(b)(1)[4] of the South Carolina Rules of Civil
  Procedure.Â  However, M&M did not ask the trial court for any sort of relief
  or request the motion be dismissed or continued in order to better prepare for
  the motion. M&M simply objected to the hearing.[5] The trial court evidently assumed
  M&M was making such a motion for a continuance and denied it.Â  M&M now
  appeals claiming it was â€œunable to properly prepare for arguing the Motion for
  Summary Judgment.â€Â  
M&M correctly asserts Holmes did not comply with the technical
  requirements of Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  However, M&M did not argue at the
  trial court that Holmesâ€™ failure to follow Rule 7(b)(1), SCRCP, prejudiced it
  or caused unfair surprise in any way.Â  As such, we find M&Mâ€™s current argument
  of prejudice is not preserved for our review. Staubes v. City of Folly Beach,
  339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the
  first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial
  court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Were we to consider the merits of this argument, this Court would
  be forced to find M&M cannot make the requisite showing of prejudice
  necessary to reverse the trial courtâ€™s denial of a continuance.Â  The grant or
  denial of a continuanceÂ  lies with the sound discretion of the trial court and
  such ruling will not be reversed absent a clear showing of abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Tanner, 299
  S.C. 459, 462, 385 S.E.2d 832, 834 (1989).Â  â€œMoreover, the denial of a motion for a continuance on the
  ground that counsel has not had time to prepare is rarely disturbed on appeal.â€ Plyler v. Burns, 373 S.C. 637, 650, 647 S.E.2d 188, 195 (2007).Â  M&M
  has demonstrated no such prejudice at either the trial court or this court.
II. Condition
  Precedent Located in a Recital
M&M
  contends the contingency in Paragraph 4 of the Contract is a recital and cannot
  be construed as a condition precedent.Â  M&M further argues summary judgment
  was inappropriate because the placement of a contingency in a recital clause
  creates a question of fact as to whether a condition precedent existed at all.Â 
  We disagree.
Paragraph
  4 of the Contract states, in full, â€œ[w]hereas, the parties agree that Buyerâ€™s
  obligation to purchase the assets of the business and Sellerâ€™s obligation to
  sell the assets is contingent upon Buyerâ€™s ability to secure commercial
  financing at prevailing interest rates.â€Â  The Contract also contains a section
  entitled â€œContingencies.â€Â  Language similar to Paragraph 4 does not appear in
  the â€œContingenciesâ€ section; however, the Contract itself states the headings
  do not define, limit, or describe the scope or intent of the Contractâ€™s
  provisions.[6]Â  
Blackâ€™s
  Law Dictionary defines â€œrecitalâ€ as â€œ[a]n account or description of some fact
  or thing; â€¦[a] preliminary statement in a contract or deed explaining the background
  of the transaction or showing the existence of particular facts.â€Â  (7th ed. 2000).Â  Recitals also traditionally begin with the word â€œwhereas.â€ Blackâ€™s
  Law Dictionary (8th ed. 2004).Â  Although whereas clauses typically
  describe the background leading to a contract, the foremost rule of contract
  interpretation is that courts â€œmust give effect to the intentions of the
  parties by looking to the language of the contract.â€ Moser v. Gosnell,
  334 S.C. 425, 430, 513 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Conner v.
    Alvarez, 285 S.C. 97, 101, 328 S.E.2d 334, 336 (1985)); see Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 199 S.E.2d 719 (1973)
  (holding the intention of an instrument is determined by its language,
  regardless of whether such language is in a whereas clause; language in a
  recital clearly set forth an agreementâ€™s purpose as a modification); Horry
    v. Frost, 10 Rich. Eq. 109, 1858 WL 3728 (Ct. App. Eq. 1858) (â€œA covenant may be as obligatory when expressed by way of recital as if expressed in the formal part of the agreement.â€).
â€œTo discover the intention of a contract, the court must first
  look to its language â€“ if the language is perfectly plain and capable of legal
  construction, it alone determines the document's force and effect.â€ Ecclesiastes
    Production Ministries v. Outparcel Assocs., L.L.C., 374 S.C. 483, 498, 649
  S.E.2d 494, 501 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing Superior Auto. Ins., 261 S.C. at
  263, 199 S.E.2d at 722); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 93, 594
  S.E.2d 485, 493 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œIf its language is plain, unambiguous, and
  capable of only one reasonable interpretation, no construction is required and
  the contract's language determines the instrument's force and effect.â€).Â  If
  practical, documents will be interpreted to give effect to all of their
  provisions. Ecclesiastes, 374 S.C. at 498, 649 S.E.2d at 502 (citations
  omitted); Brady v. Brady, 222 S.C. 242, 246-47, 72 S.E.2d 193, 195
  (1952).
The primary test of a contractâ€™s character is â€œthe intention of
  the parties, such intention to be gathered from the whole scope and effect of
  the language used.â€ Barnacle Broadcasting, Inc. v. Baker Broadcasting, Inc.,
  343 S.C. 140, 147, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000). Â â€œThe question of
  whether a provision in a contract constitutes a condition precedent is a
  question of construction dependent on the intent of the parties to be gathered from
  the language they employ.â€Â  Brewer v. Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc.,
  364 S.C. 444, 449, 613 S.E.2d 802, 805 (Ct. App. 2005) (citations omitted). Â â€œIn
  ascertaining intent, the court will strive to discover the situation of the
  parties, along with their purposes at the time the contract was entered.â€ Ellie,
  358 S.C. at 94, 594 S.E.2d at 493.Â  Parties are governed by their outward
  expressions and the court is not free to consider their secret intentions. Id. at 94, 594 S.C. at 494.Â  
In the present case, Paragraph 4 clearly states, â€œthe parties agree that Buyerâ€™s obligation to purchase
  the assets of the business and Sellerâ€™s obligation to sell the assets is
    contingent upon Buyerâ€™s ability to secure commercial financing.â€ (emphasis
  added).Â  The use of the language â€œis contingent uponâ€ is unequivocal and
  patently indicates the partiesâ€™ respective obligations to buy and sell the
  business are contingent on Holmesâ€™ ability to secure financing.Â  No other
  meaning could be deduced from such clear and commonly used language.Â  â€œWhen a contract is clear and unambiguous, the construction
  of the contract is a question of law for the court.â€ Moser, 334 S.C. at
  430, 513 S.E.2d at 125 (citing Conner, 285 S.C. at 101, 328 S.E.2d at
  336).Â  Accordingly, we agree with the trial court that Paragraph 4 of the
  Contract contains a condition precedent.Â  We will now discuss whether such
  condition was met.
III. Condition
  Precedent
M&M contends the trial court erred in awarding summary
  judgment on the basis of Holmesâ€™ inability to meet a condition precedent
  resulting in a void contract.Â  We disagree.
A condition precedent to a contract is â€œany fact other than the
  lapse of time, which, unless excused, must exist or occur before a duty of
  immediate performance arises.â€ Brewer v. Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc.,
  364 S.C. 444, 449, 613 S.E.2d 802, 805 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Worley v.
    Yarborough Ford, Inc., 317 S.C. 206, 210, 452 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App.
  1994). Â Â Here, the Contract contained a condition precedent[7] that Holmesâ€™ obligation to purchase
  the business was subject to her ability to secure commercial financing.Â  
On May 9, 2005, Holmesâ€™ request for a loan was denied. Â At
  the summary judgment hearing, no evidence was presented regarding Holmesâ€™
  ability to secure commercial financing, and no evidence was presented to show
  Holmes obtained financing by the Contractâ€™s closing date of May 22, 2005.Â  â€œThe
  failure of one to perform under a contract because of his inability to obtain
  financing from a third party on whom he relied to furnish the money will not
  excuse performance, in the absence of a contract provision in that regard.â€Â  Worley,
  317 S.C. at 209, 452 S.E.2d at 624 (citing 17A Am.Jur.2d Contracts Â§ 680
  (1991)).Â  This Contract contained just such a provision relating to Holmesâ€™
  ability to obtain financing.Â  
 In light of this
  Contractâ€™s language and the foregoing reasons, the order of the trial court
  granting summary judgment in favor of Holmes on M&Mâ€™s causes of action is
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS
  and PIEPER, JJ., concur.

[1] Initially we must note that summary judgment was
  granted solely to Holmes on M&Mâ€™s breach of contract action.Â  Although
  Holmes, Kopatch, and Empire Business Brokerage, L.L.C. are represented by the
  same attorney, the attorney made clear at the beginning of the hearing that
  Kopatch and the Brokerage were not parties to the Motion for Summary Judgment. Â As
  such, this appeal and opinion pertain only to the action against Holmes.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] â€œ19. TIME IS OF THE ESSENCE.Â  It is agreed by both Buyer and Seller that time is of the essence in all regards in
  connection with this Agreement.â€Â  (emphasis in original).
[4] Rule
  7(b)(1), SCRCP, provides, â€œ[a]n
  application to the court for an order shall be by motion which, unless made
  during a hearing or trial in open court with a court reporter present, shall be
  made in writing, shall state with particularity the grounds therefor, and shall
  set forth the relief or order sought.Â  The requirement of writing is fulfilled
  if the motion is stated in a written notice of the hearing of the motion.â€
[5] At the hearing M&Mâ€™s counsel argued, â€œFirst I
  would like to object to this Motion hearing itself in that counsel failed to
  follow Rule 7(b)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedureâ€¦ In the
  Motion itself there are no grounds whatsoever given for this Motion.Â  So I
  would like to object to it on that stance to start with.â€Â  The trial court
  stated, â€œOkay.Â  Well, that Motion is denied.â€Â  M&Mâ€™s counsel replied,
  â€œThank you. â€¦Secondly, your Honor, there are two reasons why counsel should fail
  on its Motion.â€
[6] â€œHEADINGS AND CONSTRUCTION.Â  The caption
  headings are used in this Agreement only as a matter of convenience and for
  reference and do not define, limit, or describe either the scope of this
  Agreement or the intent of any provision.â€ (emphasis in original).
[7] Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary defines â€œcondition precedentâ€
  as â€œ[a]n act or event, other than a lapse of time, that must exist or occur
  before a duty to perform something promised arises.Â  If the condition does not
  occur and is not excused, the promised performance need not be rendered.â€ (8th ed. 2004).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
				v.
				Ricky Brannon, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Cherokee County
Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4428
Submitted June 1, 2008 â€“ Filed July 18,
  2008
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Appellate Defender for Capital Appeals Robert M.
  Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Assistant Attorney General Michelle Parsons, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Appellant Ricky Brannon was convicted of resisting arrest for
  fleeing on foot from police officers who yelled, â€œStop, police.â€Â  Citing a lack
  of direct and substantial circumstantial evidence, he argues the circuit court
  judge erred in denying his motion for a directed verdict.Â  We agree.[1]
FACTUAL / PROCEDUAL BACKGROUND
Maria
  Raney, a resident of Westwood Apartments in Gaffney, awoke in the early morning
  hours of April 21, 2003.Â  Upon looking out her window, she observed her car
  with its interior light illuminated and a man moving around inside.Â  She called
  911 and the operator asked her to stay on the line until police arrived.Â 
  Rainey complied and informed the operator when she saw Gaffney Police
  Department Officers Michael Scruggs and Randy Quinn.Â  Rainey testified the
  officers â€œcame up and they hollered police and I saw them as [they] chased
  him.â€
With
  dispatch relaying information as it was supplied by Rainey, Officer Scruggs and
  Officer Quinn approached the apartment building with the headlights and sirens
  off.Â  Once in proximity, the officers proceeded on foot and observed a figure
  standing outside a vehicle whose interior light was on.Â  Raineyâ€™s observations,
  as conveyed by dispatch, informed them the suspect had moved on to another car,
  a Ford Explorer owned by a neighborâ€™s mother. Â The officers saw only one figure
  in the parking lot by an Explorer. Scruggs explained â€œ[a]t that time, we knew
  we had a crime being committed.â€Â  Scruggs said the person looked up, apparently
  hearing them.Â  Scruggs testified:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Now, when yâ€™all came up, you say you
  identified yourself.Â  Tell me exactly what you said.
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  I think Officer Quinn told him just, said just
  stop police, or I believe thatâ€™s what he said.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Okay.Â  Stop
  police.Â  Was anything else said to him?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  No, sir,
  other than stop again because he was already running.
	Q: Â Â Â Â  All right.Â  So all that was said to him was
  stop police and then stop again?Â  He was never placed under arrest?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  No, sir,
  not until we caught him.

Officer Quinn
  testified:

	
		
			Q:
			Based upon information you had, did you believe the 
			subject, at that time, was the individual breaking into motor 
			vehicles?
		
	
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir.
	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And what
  was your intention when the subject took off?
	. . .
	
		
			A:
			Our intention was to approach the subject and find 
			out exactly what he was doing there at that time.  We believe 
			he was breaking into a motor vehicle and we placed him under arrest 
			for that charge.  
		
	

Brannon ran three
  hundred to three hundred fifty yards before being placed under arrest.Â  The
  record does not indicate Brannon resisted the officers once caught.Â  Scruggs
  explained:

	Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Why was he
  charged with resisting arrest?
	A:Â Â Â Â Â  For running
  on myself and Officer Quinn.

After being found
  guilty, Brannon was sentenced to three years in prison for breaking into a
  motor vehicle, suspended upon the service of two years, and one year
  probation.Â  He was additionally sentenced to one year in prison for resisting
  arrest.Â  The sentences are concurrent.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  criminal cases, an appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State
    v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Miller,
  375 S.C. 370, 378, 652 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. App. 2007); State v. Wood,
  362 S.C. 520, 525, 608 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Thus, an appellate
  court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  Id.; State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 101, 606 S.E.2d
  503, 504 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the
  trial court abused its discretion. Â State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 43, 503
  S.E.2d 747, 751 (1998); State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 653, 623 S.E.2d
  122, 127 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The conduct of a criminal trial is left largely to
  the sound discretion of the trial judge, who will not be reversed absent a
  prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Bridges, 278 S.C. 447, 448,
  298 S.E.2d 212, 212 (1982); State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 230, 625
  S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006), cert. denied, May 3, 2007.Â  
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.  Directed
  Verdict
Brannon contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for
  directed verdict on the resisting arrest charge.
When
  ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is concerned with
  the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight.Â  State v. Weston,
  367 S.C. 279, 292, 625 S.E.2d 641, 648 (2006); State v. Stanley, 365
  S.C. 24, 41-42, 615 S.E.2d 455, 464 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Padgett, 354
  S.C. 268, 271, 580 S.E.2d 159, 161 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A defendant is entitled to
  a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense
  charged.Â  State v. Cherry, 361 S.C. 588, 593, 606 S.E.2d 475, 478 (2004)
  (citing State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 642, 576 S.E.2d 168, 171 (2003)); State v. Crawford, 362 S.C. 627, 633, 608 S.E.2d 886, 889 (Ct. App.
  2005); Padgett, 354 S.C. at 271, 580 S.E.2d at 161.Â  When reviewing a
  denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court views evidence and all
  reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the State.Â  Weston,
  367 S.C. at 292, 625 S.E.2d at 648; State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 101, 610
  S.E.2d 859, 863 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Al-Amin, 353 S.C. 405, 411,
  578 S.E.2d 32, 35 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If there is any direct evidence or
  substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of
  the accused, we must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  Weston,
  367 S.C. at 292-93, 625 S.E.2d at 648; Cherry, 361 S.C. at 593, 606
  S.E.2d at 478; McKnight, 352 S.C. at 642, 576 S.E.2d at 172; State v.
    Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 190, 562 S.E.2d 320, 323 (Ct. App. 2002); see
      also State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 563, 598 S.E.2d 279, 284 (Ct. App.
  2004) (noting judge should deny motion for directed verdict if there is any
  direct or substantial circumstantial evidence that reasonably tends to prove
  the defendantâ€™s guilt, or from which guilt may be fairly and logically
  deduced).Â  The appellate court may reverse the trial courtâ€™s denial of a motion
  for a directed verdict only if there is no evidence to support the courtâ€™s
  ruling. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).
The trial
  court should grant a directed verdict when the evidence merely raises a
  suspicion that the defendant is guilty. Â State v. Arnold, 361 S.C. 386, 390,
  605 S.E.2d 529, 531 (2004); State v. Schrock, 283 S.C. 129, 132, 322
  S.E.2d 450, 452 (1984); State v. Horne, 324 S.C. 372, 379, 478 S.E.2d
  289, 293 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œ â€˜Suspicionâ€™ implies a belief or opinion as to
  guilt based upon facts or circumstances which do not amount to proof.â€ Â Cherry,
  361 S.C. at 594, 606 S.E.2d at 478. Â However, a trial court is not required to
  find that the evidence infers guilt to the exclusion of any other reasonable
  hypothesis. Â Id.Â  
II.  Rules
  of Statutory Construction
The cardinal rule of statutory
  interpretation is to determine the intent of the legislature. Â Bass v. Isochem,
  365 S.C. 454, 459, 617 S.E.2d 369, 377 (Ct. App. 2005); Georgia-Carolina
    Bail Bonds, Inc. v. County of Aiken, 354 S.C. 18, 22, 579 S.E.2d 334, 336
  (Ct. App. 2003); Smith v. S.C. Ins. Co., 350 S.C. 82, 87, 564 S.E.2d 358,
  361 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Gordon v. Phillips Utils., Inc.,
  362 S.C. 403, 406, 608 S.E.2d 425, 427 (2005) (â€œThe primary purpose in
  construing a statute is to ascertain legislative intent.â€).Â  All rules of
  statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must
  prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that
  language must be construed in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.
  Â McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d
  240, 242 (2002); Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County,
  331 S.C. 19, 26, 501 S.E.2d 725, 729 (1998); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C.
  359, 365-66, 574 S.E.2d 203, 206 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Hudson, 336
  S.C. 237, 246, 519 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œOnce the legislature has
  made [a] choice, there is no room for the courts to impose a different judgment
  based upon their own notions of public policy.â€ Â S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins.
    Co. v. Mumford, 299 S.C. 14, 19, 382 S.E.2d 11, 14 (Ct. App. 1989).
The
  legislatureâ€™s intent should be ascertained primarily from the plain language of
  the statute. Â State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 102, 606 S.E.2d 503, 505
  (Ct. App. 2004); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Stephen
    v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 339, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  The language must be read to harmonize with its subject matter and
  accord with its general purpose.Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of S.C. v. AT & T Commcâ€™ns
    of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992); Morgan, 352 S.C. at 366, 574 S.E.2d at 206; Hudson, 336
  S.C. at 246, 519 S.E.2d at 582. Â 
When a
  statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for
  statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its
  literal meaning. Â Miller v. Aiken, 364 S.C. 303, 307, 613 S.E.2d 364,
  366 (2005); Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314
  S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994); Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto
    Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 231, 612 S.E.2d 719, 723 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If a
  statuteâ€™s language is unambiguous and clear, there is no need to employ the
  rules of statutory construction and this Court has no right to look for or
  impose another meaning. Â Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 373,
  585 S.E.2d 292, 298 (2003); Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C.
  434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995).Â  What a legislature says in the text of a
  statute is considered the best evidence of the legislative intent or will. Â Bayle
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 122, 542 S.E.2d 736, 740 (Ct. App. 2001).
  Â The words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without
  resorting to subtle or forced construction. Â Durham v. United Cos.
    Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 604, 503 S.E.2d 465, 468 (1998); Adkins v.
      Comcar Indus., Inc., 323 S.C. 409, 411, 475 S.E.2d 762, 763 (1996); Worsley
        Cos. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 351 S.C. 97, 102, 567
  S.E.2d 907, 910 (Ct. App. 2002); see also Timmons v. S.C.
    Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C. 378, 402, 175 S.E.2d 805, 817 (1970)
  (observing that where the language of the statute is clear and explicit, the
  court cannot rewrite the statute and inject matters into it that are not in the
  legislatureâ€™s language). Â Under the plain meaning rule, it is not the courtâ€™s
  place to change the meaning of a clear and unambiguous statute. Â Vaughn v.
    Bernhardt, 345 S.C. 196, 198, 547 S.E.2d 869, 870 (2001); Hodges v.
      Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000); Bayle, 344 S.C.
  at 122, 542 S.E.2d at 739; see also Shealy v. Doe, 370 S.C. 194, 199-200,
  634 S.E.2d 45, 48 (Ct. App. 2006), cert. denied, Aug. 9, 2007.
In construing a statute, the court looks to the language as a
  whole in light of its manifest purpose. Â State v. Dawkins, 352 S.C. 162,
  166, 573 S.E.2d 783, 785 (2002); Adams v. Texfi Indus., 320 S.C.
  213, 217, 464 S.E.2d 109, 112 (1995); Brassell, 326 S.C. at 560, 486
  S.E.2d at 494.Â  A statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and
  fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the
  lawmakers. Â See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. S.C. Second Injury
    Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 621, 611 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Georgia-Carolina Bail Bonds, 354 S.C. at 22, 579 S.E.2d at 336 (â€œA
  statute should be given a reasonable and practical construction consistent with
  the purpose and policy expressed in the statute.â€). Â The real purpose and
  intent of the lawmakers will prevail over the literal import of the words.Â  Browning
    v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 125, 414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992).
Courts
  will reject a statutory interpretation which would lead to a result so plainly
  absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat
  the plain legislative intention. Â Unisun Ins. Co. v. Schmidt, 339 S.C.
  362, 368, 529 S.E.2d 280, 283 (2000); Kiriakides v. United Artists Commcâ€™ns,
    Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994). Â A court should not
  consider a particular clause in a statute as being construed in isolation, but
  should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the
  policy of the law.Â  See Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 363 S.C. at
  622, 611 S.E.2d at 302; see also Mid-State Auto Auction v. Altman,
  324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996) (stating that in ascertaining the
  intent of the legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or
  provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole).
â€œFinally, when a statute is penal in nature, it must be construed strictly against the State and
  in favor of the defendant.â€Â  State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 273, 403
  S.E.2d 660, 662 (1991) (citing State v. Cutler 274, S.C. 376, 264 S.E.2d
  420 (1980)); see also State v. Dingle, 376 S.C. 643, 649-50, 659
  S.E.2d 101, 105 (2008); State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 153, 588 S.E.2d
  105, 110 (2003); Kerr v. State, 345 S.C. 183, 189, 547 S.E.2d 494, 497
  (2001); Hair v. State, 305 S.C. 77, 79, 406 S.E.2d 332, 334 (1991); State
    v. Graves, 269 S.C. 356, 360, 237 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1977) (Because statute
  at issue is penal in nature â€œwe must approach itâ€™s interpretation by invoking
  the rule of strict statutory construction and resolve any uncertainty or
  ambiguity against the State and in favor of the respondent.â€); Lewis v.
    Gaddy, 254 S.C. 66, 71, 173 S.E.2d 376, 378 (1970).
III.  Stops and Arrests
The
  Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitutionâ€”applicable to the states
  through the Fourteenth Amendmentâ€”guarantees â€œ[t]he right of the people to be
  secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable
  searches and seizures.â€Â  U.S. Const. amends. IV & XIV; State v. Pichardo,
  367 S.C. 84, 97, 623 S.E.2d 840, 847 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Union
    Pac. Ry. Co. v. Botsford, 141 U.S. 250, 251 (1891) (â€œNo right is held more
  sacred, or is more carefully guarded by the common law, than the right of every
  individual to the possession and control of his own person, free from all
  restraint or interference of others, unless by clear and unquestionable
  authority of law.â€).
A
  police officer may stop and briefly detain and question a person for
  investigative purposes, without treading upon his Fourth Amendment rights, when
  the officer has a reasonable suspicion supported by articulable facts, short of
  probable cause for arrest, that the person is involved in criminal activity.Â  Terry
    v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1 (1968); State v. Robinson, 306 S.C. 399, 412
  S.E.2d 411 (1991); State v. Foster, 269 S.C. 373, 237 S.E.2d 589 (1977); State v. Woodruff, 344 S.C. 537, 546, 544 S.E.2d 290, 295 (Ct. App. 2001).Â 
  The term â€œreasonable suspicionâ€ requires a particularized and objective basis
  that would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity.Â  United States v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411 (1981); State v. Lesley, 326 S.C. 641,
  486 S.E.2d 276 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In determining whether reasonable suspicion
  exists, the whole picture must be considered.Â  United States v.
    Sokolow, 490 U.S. 1 (1989); State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 248,
  525 S.E.2d 535, 539 (Ct. App. 1999).
The
  test for determining if a particular encounter constitutes a seizure within the
  meaning of the Fourth Amendment is whether in view of all the circumstances
  surrounding the incident, a reasonable person would have believed that he was
  not free to leave.Â  Michigan v. Chesternut, 486 U.S. 567 (1988); United
    States v. Analla, 975 F.2d 119 (4th Cir.1992); see also United States v. Sullivan, 138 F.3d 126, 132 (4th Cir. 1998) (â€œThe test ...
  [is] whether, under the totality of the circumstances surrounding the
  encounter, a reasonable person in the suspectâ€™s position â€˜would have felt free
  to decline the officerâ€™s requests or otherwise terminate the encounter.â€™â€)
  (citations omitted).Â  So long as the person to whom questions are put remains
  free to disregard the questions and walk away, there has been no intrusion upon
  that personâ€™s liberty or privacy as would under the Constitution require some
  particularized and objective justification.Â  United States v.
    Mendenhall, 446 U.S. 544 (1980).Â  The test is necessarily imprecise,
  because it is designed to assess the coercive effect of police conduct taken as
  a whole.Â  Chesternut, 486 U.S. at 573; State v. Williams, 351
  S.C. 591, 600, 571 S.E.2d 703, 708 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Thus, exactly what
  constitutes a restraint on liberty sufficient to lead a reasonable person to
  conclude he is not free to leave varies with the setting in which the police
  conduct occurs.Â  Id.
Reasonableness
  is measured in objective terms by examining the totality of the circumstances.Â  Ohio v. Robinette, 519 U.S. 33 (1996); Williams, 351 S.C.
  at 600, 571 S.E.2d at 708.Â  As a result, the nature of the reasonableness
  inquiry is highly fact-specific.Â  Id.Â  Although no single factor
  dictates whether a seizure has occurred, courts have identified certain
  probative factors, including the time and place of the encounter, the existence
  and nature of any prior seizure, whether there was a clear and expressed
  endpoint to any such prior detention, the number of officers present and
  whether they were uniformed, the length of the detention, whether the officer
  moved the person to a different location or isolated him from others, whether
  the officer informed the person he was free to leave, whether the officer
  indicated to the person that he was suspected of a crime, and whether the
  officer retained the personâ€™s documents or exhibited threatening behavior or
  physical contact.Â  Pichardo, 367 S.C. at 101, 623 S.E.2d at 849.Â  See
    also United States v. Beck, 140 F.3d 1129 (8th Cir. 1998); Ferris
      v. State, 735 A.2d 491 (Md. 1999).
â€œIf
  the officerâ€™s suspicions are confirmed or are further aroused, the stop may be
  prolonged and the scope enlarged as required by the circumstances.â€Â  State
    v. Culbreath, 300 S.C. 232, 236, 387 S.E.2d 255, 257 (1990), abrogated
      on other grounds by Horton v. California, 496 U.S. 128 (1990).Â  Even
  where the stop is deemed proper, â€œbefore the police may frisk a defendant, they
  must have a reasonable belief the defendant is armed and dangerous.â€Â  State
    v. Fowler, 322 S.C. 263, 267, 471 S.E.2d 706, 708 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In assessing
  whether a suspect is armed and dangerous, the officer need not be absolutely
  certain the individual is armed.Â  Terry, 392 U.S. at 27; State v.
    Smith, 329 S.C. 550, 556, 495 S.E.2d 798, 801 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The issue
  is whether a reasonably prudent man in the circumstances would be warranted in
  the belief that his safety or that of others was in danger.Â  Terry, 392 U.S. at 27; Smith, 329 S.C. at 556, 495 S.E.2d at 801.
â€œReasonable
  suspicion is a lesser standard than probable cause and allows an officer to
  effectuate a stop when there is some objective manifestation of criminal
  activity involving the person stopped.â€Â  State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268,
  273, 580 S.E.2d 159, 162 (Ct. App. 2003); see also State v. Willard,
  374 S.C. 129, 134, 647 S.E.2d 252, 255 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Probable cause for a
  warrantless arrest exists when the circumstances within the arresting officerâ€™s
  knowledge are sufficient to lead a reasonable person to believe that a crime
  has been committed by the person being arrested.Â  State v. Baccus, 367
  S.C. 41, 49, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220 (2006); State v. Moultrie, 316 S.C. 547,
  552, 451 S.E.2d 34, 37 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  We discussed probable cause in the
  case of State v. Blassingame:

	The
  fundamental question in determining the lawfulness of an arrest is whether
  probable cause existed to make the arrest.Â  Wortman v. City of Spartanburg, 310 S.C. 1, 425 S.E.2d 18 (1992).Â  â€œProbable cause is defined as a good
  faith belief that a person is guilty of a crime when this belief rests on such
  grounds as would induce an ordinarily prudent and cautious person, under the
  circumstances, to believe likewise.â€Â  Id. at 4, 425 S.E.2d at 20.Â  Probable

  kind that the law typically associates with a formal arrest.â€).Â  Without
  a doubt, Brannon was â€œconscious of [the] restraint of his liberty.â€Â  State
    v. Williams, 237 S.C. at 257, 116 S.E.2d at 861.
An
  arrest is defined as depriving a â€œperson of his liberty by legal authority.â€Â 
  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 109 (6th ed. 1990).Â  The definition continues to
  explain, â€œ[a]ll that is required for an â€˜arrestâ€™ is some act by officer indicating
  his intention to detain or take person into custody and thereby subject that
  person to the actual control and will of the officer.â€Â  Id. at 110.Â 
  This comprehensive definition lines up with other authorities addressing the
  breadth and scope of the concept of arrest.Â  See 6A CJS Arrest Â§ 1 (2004) (â€œAn arrest is the taking, seizing, or
  detaining the person of another by any act which indicates an intention to take
  him or her into custody and subject the person arrested to the actual control
  and will of the person making the arrest.â€).
I
  will respond briefly to other South Carolina cases cited by the majority.Â  As
  an initial observation, neither the facts nor law of these cases warrants
  reversal of Brannonâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  The focus of Bouie was
  whether the defendant resisted arrest by a â€œmomentary delay in
  responding to the officerâ€™s command.â€Â  239 S.C. at 574, 124 S.E.2d at 333.Â  Bouie says nothing about the meaning of the term â€œarrest.â€Â  Id.Â  In Fernandez
    v. State, 306 S.C. 264, 265, 411, S.E.2d 426, 427 (1991), Fernandez was
  simply standing among a group of people.Â  There was no reason to believe that
  Fernandez was engaged in any criminal activity.Â  Id.Â  Yet Fernandez ran
  as police officers approached, prompting the officers to pursue.Â  Id.Â  During the pursuit Fernandez discarded drugs.Â  Id.Â  The legal issue in
  Fernandez was determining at what point the defendant had been â€œseizedâ€ under
  the Fourth Amendment for purposes of ruling on his motion to suppress.Â  Id.Â  The meaning of the term â€œarrestâ€ in section 16-9-320 played no role in Fernandez.Â  Id.
I
  view the matter of legislative intent of the statutory term â€œarrestâ€ under
  section 16-9-320 as a different proposition from the purely constitutional
  question of what constitutes a â€œseizureâ€ under the Fourth Amendment.Â  The
  concepts may often overlap, but I do not believe that an arrest under section
  16-9-320 must be construed in exact parity with a Fourth Amendment seizure.
A
  Fourth Amendment seizure is always an act, never a process.Â  See California
    v. Hodari, 499 U.S. 621, 629 (1991) (holding the subject was only seized
  when he was tackled by an officer); Brower v. County of Inyo, 489 U.S.
  593, 596-99 (1989) (stating a roadblock was a seizure as a seizure occurs â€œonly
  when there is a governmental termination of freedom of movement through
    means intentionally appliedâ€) (emphasis in original)); Thompson v.
      Whitman, 85 U.S. 457, 471 (1873) (stating that, in a vessel seizure case,
  â€œ[a] seizure is a single act, and not a continuous factâ€); Blackâ€™s Law
  Dictionary 1363 (7th ed. 1999) (defining seizure as â€œ[t]he act of an instance
  of taking possession of a person or property by legal right or processâ€).Â  Conversely,
  as State v. Dowd instructs, the term â€œarrestâ€ in section 16-9-320
  contemplates a process.Â  306 S.C. at 270, 411 S.E.2d at 429.
Moreover,
  even a limited Terry v. Ohio[4] detention based on articulable suspicion constitutes a seizure under the Fourth
  Amendment.Â  See Brendlin v. California, 551 U.S. Â Â Â Â Â , 127 S. Ct. 2400, 2405 (2007) (holding that â€œ[a] person is seized by the police
  and thus entitled to challenge the
  governmentâ€™s action under the Fourth Amendment when the officer, â€˜ â€œby means of
  physical force or show of authority,â€ â€™ terminates or restrains his freedom of
  movementâ€) (quoting Florida v. Bostick, 501 U.S. 429, 434 (1991)
  (quoting Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 19, n.16 (1968))).Â  Yet we all
  acknowledge that an individual fleeing from an attempted Terry v. Ohio detention would not constitute resisting arrest under section 16-9-320, for the
  element of arrest would be lacking.Â  That scenario presents a Fourth Amendment
  seizure but not an arrest under section 16-9-320.Â  I therefore conclude that it
  is inappropriate to equate a Fourth Amendment seizure with the term â€œarrestâ€ in
  section 16-9-320.
The
  majority has done a laudable effort in citing to statutes and case law from
  other jurisdictions.Â  I see no reason to rely so heavily on the law of other
  jurisdictions.Â  I believe our jurisprudence is sufficient to resolve this
  appeal.Â  And if my reliance on South Carolina law, with its common law
  antecedents, for discerning the meaning of the statutory term â€œarrestâ€ is
  misplaced, I believe our supreme court should resolve the matter and its
  concomitant policy implications.
I
  add one final observation that I believe supports my assessment of legislative
  intent of the term â€œarrestâ€ in section 16-9-320.Â  The Legislature created two
  separate offenses for resisting arrest.Â  Brannon was convicted of violating
  subsection (A) of section 16-9-320, which makes it a one-year misdemeanor to
  merely resist arrest.Â  The Legislature further enacted subsection (B) of
  section 16-9-320, which makes it a ten-year felony to assault an officer while
  resisting an arrest.Â  Subsection (B) states:

	It
  is unlawful for a person to knowingly and wilfully . . . assault, beat, or
  wound an officer when the person is resisting an arrest being made by one whom
  the person knows or reasonably should know is a law enforcement officer,
  whether under process or not. A person who violates the provisions of this
  subsection is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be fined not less
  than one thousand dollars nor more than ten thousand dollars or imprisoned not
  more than ten years, or both.

Subsection (B)
  provides an enhanced penalty when a defendant assaults, beats, or wounds the
  arresting officer.Â  It is in subsection (B) where we find the physicality
  component which is a feature of the majority opinion.Â  Construing resisting
  arrest under the subsection (A) misdemeanor offense in line with the broad
  common law understanding of the term is a reasonable construction, and one that
  comports with the marked distinction given the separate offenses by the
  Legislature.
The majorityâ€™s
  bright line approach of an actual, hands-on seizure would most assuredly
  facilitate application of section 16-9-320.Â  Yet I believe such a formulaic
  approach would result in artificial distinctions not intended by the
  Legislature.Â  Say, for example, a police officer has probable cause to arrest
  an individual and the suspect is aware of the officerâ€™s intent to arrest him.Â 
  In one scenario, the officer approaches the suspect but the suspect flees as
  the officerâ€™s attempt to grab the suspect comes up inches short.Â  In a second
  scenario, the same facts are present except the officer has a momentary grasp
  of the suspect before the suspect flees.Â  Did the Legislature intend for the
  resisting arrest statute to apply in the second scenario but not the first?Â  I
  think not.Â  Moreover, a consideration of the facts of each case, as I propose,
  gives meaning to the holding in State v. Williams that an arrest may
  occur without the application of actual force or manual touching of the body.Â  237
  S.C. at 257, 116 S.E.2d at 860.
In
  sum, I vote to affirm and adhere to my view that the reasoning of the majority
  opinion includes arguments never advanced by Brannon at trial or in his brief.Â 
  I would affirm on issue preservation principles and the law of the case
  doctrine.Â  I do address the substance of the majority opinion, albeit with
  reservation because of the policy implications involved.Â  In voting to affirm
  the denial of the directed verdict motion, I would apply our resisting arrest
  statute to a fleeing suspect only in very narrow circumstances.Â  As emphasized
  above, under the particular facts of this case, when objectively viewed, it is
  the presence of probable cause to believe that Brannon was committing a felony
  that gives rise to the application of the misdemeanor offense of resisting
  arrest under subsection (A) of 16-9-320.Â  I would hold that a person violates
  section 16-9-320(A) irrespective of the lack of physical contact: (1) when a
  law enforcement officer, from an objective standpoint, has probable cause to
  believe a person has committed a crime; and (2) the law enforcement officer
  through words or actions makes known his intent to arrest or otherwise detain
  the person; and (3) the person, from an objective standpoint, recognizes the
  presence of a law enforcement officer and understands the intent of the officer
  to arrest him; and (4) the person attempts to avoid the arrest by impeding,
  hindering, or obstructing the law enforcement officer, by means of fleeing from
  the officer or other method of resisting or opposing the arrest.Â  This initial
  offense would terminate upon the full custodial arrest of the suspect or the
  suspension of the pursuit by the law enforcement officer.
Viewing
  the evidence and the reasonable inferences in a light most favorable to the
  State, I would find a jury question was presented as to the charge of resisting
  arrest under section 16-9-320(A).Â  I would affirm the denial of the directed
  verdict motion.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  The jury was charged that â€œ[r]esist means to
  oppose, strive against, or obstruct or obstruct by means to impede, hinder, or
  interfere with.â€ 
[3]  This assessment is admittedly problematic, for
  the jury was never charged on the law of â€œarrestâ€ under section 16-9-320.Â  This
  difficulty highlights the soundness of issue preservation rules which are
  designed to ensure that the issues considered on appeal are the same ones
  raised in the trial court.
[4]  Terry v. Ohio,
  392 U.S. 1 (1968).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Carrie Williams
          and Robert Williams, Appellants,
        v.
        Nancy Watkins
          and Babcock Center, Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4429
  Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 23,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Hemphill P. Pride, II, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Christian Stegmaier, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KONDUROS, J.:Â  This appeal arises from the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary
  judgment in favor of Babcock Center and its employee, Nancy Watkins, on Carrie
  and Robert Williamsesâ€™ claims for defamation and the intentional infliction of
  emotional distress. Â On appeal, the Williamses argue the court erred in finding
  South Carolinaâ€™s Omnibus Adult Protection Act shields Babcock Center and Watkins from civil liability for claims stemming from their reporting the suspected
  abuse of a vulnerable adult.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
In
  1991, the Department of Social Services (DSS) placed an eight-year old, disabled
  child (Client) in Carrie Williamsâ€™s (Caregiverâ€™s) licensed, therapeutic foster
  care home. Â Caregiverâ€™s husband, Robert Williams, also lived in the home.[2]Â  Caregiver subsequently contracted with Babcock Center to operate a CTH, and she continued to care for Client in her home until
2004.Â  
On January 7, 2004, while attending a program at Babcock Center, Client told administrator, Nancy Watkins, of specific actions toward her by
  Caregiverâ€™s husband.Â  Client was now twenty-one years old, and Watkins believed
  the conduct Client described to her was sexually abusive. Â Watkins immediately notified
  consulting psychologist, Dr. Wilton Hellams, of Clientâ€™s disclosure.Â  That
  evening, Client met with Dr. Hellams and repeated her specific allegations
  against Caregiverâ€™s husband. Â Following the counseling session, Dr. Hellams told
  Watkins he found Clientâ€™s allegations to be credible.Â  As a result, Watkins immediately
  moved Client to a respite-care home. Â 
Pursuant to South Carolina law, DDSN regulations,
  and Babcock Center policy, the following day, Watkins reported Clientâ€™s statements
  to the Sheriffâ€™s Department and the Adult Protective Services (APS) Program of DSS.
  Â Three months later, DSS notified Watkins its investigation had indicated â€œthere
  was a potential for abuseâ€ of Client in Caretakerâ€™s home. Â Upon receiving the
  APS report, the Center terminated its CTH contract with Caretaker. Â 
Subsequently, Caretaker and her husband
  filed an action against Babcock Center and Watkins alleging defamation and the intentional
  infliction of emotional distress.Â  As an affirmative defense to these claims, Babcock Center and Watkins asserted South Carolinaâ€™s Omnibus Adult Protection Act shielded them
  from civil and criminal liability related to reporting Clientâ€™s statements
  alleging sexual abuse by Caretakerâ€™s husband.Â  The circuit court conducted a
  hearing on September 23, 2005, and granted summary judgment on both actions in favor
  of Babcock Center and Watkins.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  reviewing the grant of summary judgment, this court applies the same standard
  that governs the trial court; summary judgment is proper when there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment
  as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857,
  860 (2002); see also Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  â€œOn appeal from an order
  granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities,
  conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most
  favorable to the appellant . . . .â€Â  Willis v. Wu., 362 S.C. 146, 151,
  607 S.E.2d 63, 65 (2004).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œplain,
  palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€
  Â Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 445, 415 S.E.2d 796, 799 (1992).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Caretaker and her
  husband argue the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment in favor of Babcock Center and Watkins because genuine issues of material fact remain regarding their
  actions for defamation and the intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â 
  We disagree. 
The Omnibus Adult
  Protection Act
In
  1993, South Carolinaâ€™s General Assembly enacted the Omnibus Adult Protection
  Act (â€œthe Actâ€) to protect vulnerable adults from abuse, neglect, and
  exploitation.Â  1993 Act No. 110, Â§ 1, codified as S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 43-35-5 to -595
  (Supp. 2007).[3]Â  
A. Vulnerable Adults 
The
  Act promulgated statutes designed to protect a class of adults from abuse,
  neglect, and exploitation.Â  The Act defines a â€œvulnerable adultâ€ as:

  [A]
    person eighteen years of age or older who has a physical or mental condition
    which substantially impairs the person from adequately
    providing for his or her own care or protection. Â This includes a person who is
    impaired in the ability to adequately provide for the personâ€™s own care or
    protection because of the infirmities of aging including, but not limited to,
    organic brain damage, advanced age, and physical, mental, or emotional dysfunction.
    Â A resident of a facility is a vulnerable adult. Â Â 

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-10 (Supp. 2007). [4] 
We
  find Client is a â€œvulnerable adultâ€ under the Act because she is over eighteen
  years old, unable to provide for her own care or protection, and a resident of
  a facility.Â  Accordingly, Client is entitled to special protections from abuse,
  neglect, and exploitation. Â 
B. Mandated Reporters 
The
  Act imposes a duty on certain individuals to report if they have â€œreason to
  believe that a vulnerable adult has been or is likely to be abused, neglected,
  or exploited.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-25(A) (Supp. 2007). Â Individuals
  designated as â€œmandated reportersâ€ under the Act include physicians, nurses,
  dentists, optometrists, medical examiners, coroners, and other medical, mental
  health or allied health professionals, Christian Science practitioners,
  religious healers, school teachers, counselors, psychologists, mental health or
  mental retardation specialists, social or public assistance workers, caregivers,
  staff or volunteers of an adult day care center or facilities, and law
  enforcement officers. Â Id. Â Furthermore, the Act also requires reporting
  by â€œany other person who has actual knowledge that a vulnerable adult has been
  abused, neglected, or exploited.â€ Â Id.[5]Â 
  Reporting the suspected conduct within twenty-four hours or the following
  working day is the reporterâ€™s individual responsibility.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  43-35-25(C)-(D) (Supp. 2007).Â  Provided the Actâ€™s mandatory reporting
  requirements are met, the reporter may additionally report suspected abuse,
  neglect, or exploitation directly to law enforcement; â€œand in cases of emergency,
  serious injury, or suspected sexual assault, law enforcement must be contacted immediately.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-25(G) (Supp.
  2007). Â 
We
  find Watkinsâ€™s duties as a social worker and program administrator make her a
  mandated reporter under the Act.Â  Accordingly, the Act imposes a duty on her to
  report Clientâ€™s statements, which gave Watkins â€œreason to believeâ€ Caregiverâ€™s
  husband sexually assaulted Client.Â  Additionally, because Watkins suspected
  sexual assault, the Act required her to report Clientâ€™s statements to both APS and law enforcement.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-25 (Supp. 2007).Â  
At
  the hearing before the circuit court, Caregiverâ€™s counsel contended Watkins â€œshould
  have considered the source and nature of the complaint.â€ Â In stating Watkins â€œreported
  a spurious allegation made by a profoundly mentally and physically handicapped
  young lady,â€ counsel implies allegations of abusive conduct made by a
  vulnerable adult, such as Client, should be taken less seriously by a mandated
  reporter than if they were made by a functionally-average adult.Â  Clearly, such
  an interpretation is contrary to the General Assemblyâ€™s intent to provide enhanced
  protections to adults who are particularly vulnerable to mistreatment.Â  Moreover,
  we believe the General Assembly established brief time limits for reporting
  precisely to discourage second-guessing by mandated reporters.Â  
The
  Act defines abuse, neglect, and exploitation; however, neither the Act nor our
  courts have addressed the perspective from which a mandated reporter should
  view the vulnerable adultâ€™s allegations.Â  The Minnesota Court of Appeals specifically
  addressed this question while construing a statute under its similar, Vulnerable
  Adults Act.Â  In re Kleven, 736 N.W.2d 707 (Minn. Ct. App. 2007).Â  In Kleven,
  an employee of a group home for disabled men argued the verbal abuse she
  allegedly had inflicted upon the men should be viewed from the perspective of
  the residents, all vulnerable adults, rather than from the perspective of a
  reasonable person.Â  Id. at 710. Â However, the court held in Kleven that to accept such an argument â€œwould mean that the more vulnerable the adult,
  the worse his caretaker could permissibly treat him.Â  . . .Â  [This]
  interpretation is an affront to the purpose of the act and leads to absurd
  results, which we presume the legislature did not intend.â€ Â Id. at 711. Â 
We
  find Watkins, by promptly reporting Clientâ€™s statements to APS and law
  enforcement, acted precisely as the Act intended.
C. Immunity from Liability
Having
  determined Client is a vulnerable adult and Watkins is a mandated reporter,
  whose duty to report was triggered by Clientâ€™s statements, we turn next to
  whether the Act shields Watkins and Babcock Center from civil and criminal
  liability that could otherwise arise from the act of reporting.Â  

  A
    person who, acting in good faith, reports pursuant to this chapter or who
    participates in an investigation or judicial proceeding resulting from a report
    is immune from civil and criminal liability which may otherwise result by
    reason of this action. Â In a civil or criminal proceeding good faith is a
    rebuttable presumption.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-75(A)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  
According to the affidavit of APS supervisor, Judy Irvin,
  Watkins reported Clientâ€™s suspected sexual abuse â€œin good faith.â€Â  Furthermore, under the Act, a report of the abuse,
  neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable adult is presumably made â€œin good
  faith.â€ Â Caretaker fails to produce evidence that defeats the presumption that
  Watkins reported in good faith.Â  Additionally, our review of the record
  confirms Watkins reported Clientâ€™s suspected abuse in good faith.Â  Accordingly,
  we conclude Watkins and Babcock Center are immune from any potential liability
flowing from the report.[6]
D. Penalties for Failure
  to Report 
Caretaker
  and her husband further allege Watkins improperly reported Clientâ€™s allegations
  to the Sheriffâ€™s Department and DSS.Â  We disagree.
To
  the contrary, a mandated reporter who has actual knowledge that abuse, neglect,
  or exploitation of a vulnerable adult has occurred, and who knowingly and willfully
  fails to report this knowledge is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction,
  the person must be fined in an amount up to $2,500 or imprisoned up to
  one year. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-85(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  Furthermore, a mandated
  reporter with reason to believe abuse, neglect, or exploitation of a vulnerable
  adult has occurred, or is likely to occur, and who knowingly and willfully
  fails to report is subject to disciplinary action by the appropriate licensing
  board.Â  Id.Â  Therefore, we find Watkins properly reported Clientâ€™s
  allegations to law enforcement and DSS.
CONCLUSION
Finding no genuine
  issue exists as to any material fact, we hold the Act entitles Watkins and Babcock Center to immunity from all civil and criminal liability related to their good
  faith report of the suspected abuse of a vulnerable adult.Â  Additionally, under
  these facts, a failure to report the suspected sexual abuse would have resulted
  in a violation of the law, subjected a mandated reporter to penalties, and most
  importantly, subjected a vulnerable adult to the continuing potential for
  abuse.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., and SHORT, J., concur.


[1] This case was decided without oral argument pursuant
to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The
  South Carolina Department of Disabilities and Special Needs (DDSN) contracted
  with Babcock Center to provide programs for vulnerable adults and to supervise
  their care in licensed community training
homes (CTHs).Â  
[3] The purpose of the Act was to: address the continuing
  needs of vulnerable adults; define abuse, neglect, and exploitation in a
  uniform manner, without regard to setting; clarify reporting requirements; provide
  victims with emergency protective custody; define the courtâ€™s role in adult
  protection; and provide civil and criminal penalties to perpetrators of the abuse,
  neglect, or exploitation of vulnerable adults.Â  S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 43-35-5 (Supp. 2007).
[4] Under the Act, a â€œfacilityâ€ includes a nursing care,
  community residential care, or psychiatric facility, as well as any other
  â€œresidential program operated or contracted for operation by the Department of
  Mental Health or [DDSN].â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-35-10(4) (Supp. 2007).
[5] Moreover, the Act encourages voluntary reporting:
  â€œ[A]ny person who has reason to believe that a vulnerable adult has been or may
  be abused, neglected, or exploited may report the incident.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§43-35-25(B)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  
[6] Richland County Deputy Terry Cryer interviewed Client and stated he found the
  allegations had merit.Â  Moreover, the DSS report stated Watkins reported in good faith and â€œthere was
potential for abuseâ€ in Caretakerâ€™s licensed CTH.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Elbert W.
          Breeze, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4430
  Submitted June 2, 2008 â€“ Filed July 23,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission
          on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Christina J. Catoe, Office of the Attorney General, all of
          Columbia; and Solicitor Robert Mills Ariail of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: In
  this criminal case, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s determination that Elbert
  Breeze (Breeze) properly waived his Miranda[1] rights.Â  We also affirm the trial courtâ€™s
  decision not to charge the jury that an adverse inference could be suggested
  from the Stateâ€™s failure to preserve the marijuana.Â  
FACTS
Officer
  Michael Collier (Collier) of the South Carolina Highway Patrol was observing a
  driverâ€™s license checkpoint in Greenville County, South Carolina.Â  Collier
  observed Breeze approach the checkpoint, abruptly stop, and jerk his car into a
  driveway without using a turn signal.Â  Collier approached Breeze and requested
  Breeze provide his driverâ€™s license.Â  In response to this request, Breeze â€œtook
  off running.â€Â  
Collier
  chased Breeze, pushed him to the ground, and ordered him to remain down.Â 
  Breeze got up, and Collier responded by using pepper spray on him.Â  Breeze still
  managed to get up and run.Â  Collier again chased and pushed Breeze to the
  ground.Â  This series of events occurred a few more times until additional
  officers arrived to assist Collier.Â  Breeze was once again sprayed with pepper
  spray, subdued, and arrested. After Breeze was placed in handcuffs, officers
  offset the effects of the pepper spray by decontaminating Breeze with an
  aerosol water bottle.Â  
After
  Breezeâ€™s arrest, Officer Johnny Black (Black) of the South Carolina Highway
  Patrol informed Breeze of his Miranda rights.Â  Subsequently, Breeze was
  searched based on a search incident to the arrest.Â  This search revealed a
  substance, which was later tested to be marijuana.Â  The total weight of the
  marijuana was 394.34 grams.Â  After being informed of his Miranda rights,
  Breeze admitted to the officer the marijuana belonged to him.Â  Breeze stated he
  ran because he â€œhad five bags of marijuana in his pockets . . . .â€Â  
Breeze argued he did not freely and voluntarily waive his right to
  remain silent.Â  The trial court found the State had proved Breeze â€œvoluntarily
  and intelligently gave up his rights and that his statement was voluntary.â€Â  
Prior to trial, the State informed Breeze the marijuana had been
  destroyed.Â  Breeze asked the trial judge to charge the jury with the following:
  â€œWhen a party loses or destroys evidence, an inference may be drawn that the
  destroyed or lost evidence would have been adverse to that party.â€Â  The trial
  judge denied this request. 
Following a jury trial, Breeze was convicted of possession of marijuana
  with intent to distribute and resisting arrest.Â  Breeze was sentenced to seven
  years for the possession with intent to distribute charge and one year for the
  resisting arrest charge.Â  The sentences were to run consecutively.Â  This appeal
  follows.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State
  v. Miller, 375 S.C. 370, 378, 652 S.E.2d 444, 448 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  Thus,
  we are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  Id.
